item.title: Spell
item.description:
Spellcasting is a general title that applies to a specific type of magical effect, with specific rules. Spells do not encompass all magic, but it is the most common type. Most Spells are Techniques.
All spells have some kind of visual effect associated with their casting before the effect occurs. Magic circles shining fingers and eyes, words manifesting into physical objects and circling the caster are all means to easily identify when a creature is casting a spell. The only exception to this is spells with the Subtle tag.
This is also the case for Innate Casting.
Spellcasting takes into account your Caster Level and Spell Power, and requires using Somatic, Material, and Verbal Components (Innate Casting does not require components).

item.title: Damage
item.description:
Damage is a value that subtracts from a target's HP when the effect takes place. "Losing HP" is synonymous with taking Damage.
Damage is always assigned a type. The physical damage types are Crush, Slash, and Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/Pierce, and the elemental types are Magic, Lightning, Fire, Cold, Holy, Necrotic, and Psychic. These are also Tags.If something deals multiple damage types, it usually adds both tags to the effect. For example, a flaming sword will deal Fire and Slash damage with its total damage, rather than separate d6 slash and d4 fire. Fire and Cold effects are mutually exclusive.
For Weapons, damage is determined by the weapon used and adds your STR. A Technique may add to this as well.
For Spell, this value is determined by your LV and SP. Any given effect will describe how to determine the damage it deals.

item.title: Natural Healing
item.description:
Naturally Healing requires eating Food. Food restores varying amounts of HP based on the food eaten. You must take a Short Rest or Long Rest to eat food. The amount recovered is based on the food.
With a Long Rest, a character restores all of their HP and all of their Limited abilities and spent Mana. You can only Long Rest once each day. You must have eaten at least once since the last time you Long Rested (or eat during the Long Rest), or else you will not recover HP.
A proper Long Rest requires being in a safe environment with the minimum necessary accommodations to not ache in one's sleep. Lacking any of these requirements results in only restoring half of one's missing HP, or less if the situation is worse, at the DM's discretion. If you are interrupted but spent at least 15 minutes resting, it counts as a Short Rest.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Hitpoints/Natural Healing.md

item.title: Short Rest
item.description: Taking a Short Rest requires being in a place with no immediate threats or hazards for at least 15 minutes, where you can eat and stretch and wipe your brow to benefit from Natural Healing. During a Short Rest, you can Prepare Techniques.

item.title: Food
item.description:
Food is one of the most common and necessary consumable resources to survive difficult journeys and dangerous dungeons. It is the slower, more efficient alternative to potions, which may grant their benefits briefly or in smaller amounts at a moment's notice.It is assumed all food items are portioned properly as a meal, and cooked to preserve. They never spoil as long as they are handled properly and are not damaged directly, such as by fire. Raw ingredients will spoil unless cooked.Food is consumed during a Short Rest over 15 minutes, unless otherwise stated.
Food primarily restores HP, but may grant bonus effects until you eat again or Long Rest.The value of a particular food increases with how much it heals/what it grants and how little it weighs.

item.title: Class and Weapon Abilities
item.description:
Class and Weapon abilities are not true Techniques, as they lack tiers (and thus do not scale with Upcast), and cannot be learned with Technique Points. They are very similar in function, however.
They are almost always Innate Techniques gained through your Class, Feats, Magic Items, and wielding Weapons that have them.
Special Attacks also fall into this category. They are written separately for cataloguing and reference purposes.Weapon abilities often list compatibility, but these compatibilities are not immutable. Particularly powerful weapons may have seemingly incompatible abilities, to represent their unique position.
item.guid: Techniques/Class and Weapon Abilities/Class and Weapon Abilities.md

item.title: Special Attack
item.description:
Special Attacks are qualities that a Weapon can have that temporarily grant you a Technique-like ability as long as you wield them. See Class and Weapon Abilities. You must use the weapon when performing the Special Attack. As per the Mana rules, you cannot sacrifice your own Mana to get another use of a Limited Innate Technique unless otherwise stated.
Special Attacks uses are also tied to the weapon - If you use the Special Attack, you cannot pass the weapon off to another creature to use it again, and the weapon has its own Recharge timer. This means you can't take the Recharge action and then pass it off to another creature to use their own Recharge.

Opponents that Grab you in return can continue the Grab as if they are Grabbing.Special: Multiple creatures can Grab one creature. item.title: Innate Technique
item.description:
Some Techniques can be granted outside of the standard progression, such as when gained from Race, Class, magic item, specialized training, or a boon granted by another creature. Not all Techniques gained in this way are innate - these are much more common on monsters.
Innate Techniques acquired by players do not take up Mana slots and are always prepared. Monsters usually have their natural abilities represented by Innate Techniques, and as such are usually made with an amount equal to their Mana.
Innate Techniques grant creatures the ability to use Techniques without the usual requirements. Spells do not require the Staff component that other casting typically requires. If a spell has a material or focus component, that is also ignored with innate casting. Concentration spells can still be ended with a Disarm Combat Maneuver. Only one Concentration effect can be upkept in this way.Unless otherwise specified, you cannot re-prepare limited innate techniques to regain their use.
If a creature's innate constant spell is deactivated, it can reactivate it as a Swift Action.

item.title: Random YouTube Comment
item.description: "As someone who comes from D&D, another very customiseable game, the "just fix it yourself" mentality is so pervasive even though the whole reason we use a tabletop RPG SYSTEM is that it should minimise how much actual game design non-game designers (i.e. players) should be doing. The best example of people being forced into the "game designer" position (who really shouldn't have been) is this well known issue that it wasn't worth casting healing spells in combat because they healed so little compared to incoming damage. Healers, who also have potent offensive magic, would just let people get to zero HP, then resuscitate them right before their turn with the weakest, lowest commitment healing spell so they both at least get to do some damage before the injured person goes down from the next thing that breathes on them. This was called "yo-yo healing" because combat would become a whack-a-mole game of people going down, then up and down again. For some reason, it became really popular to punish going unconscious with debuffs. This is like seeing smoke and trying to fan it away while making the fire underneath worse. Great, now the situation you don't really have the tools to avoid now punishes you further. With such a terrible "fix" being so popular, clearly being a game designer isn't an easy, "anyone can do it" job. It takes years of experience to get good at it. Most people were unable to identify the root cause of "yo-yo healing", which was eventually correctly addressed as low healing output 10 years later by the actual game designers when they buffed healing magic. That being said, the average player, and even modder, likely isn't that great at even identifying WHY something is a problem or why something is causing them to have less fun. After I started playing with KeepInventory, I started feeling dissatisfied after a while of using death as a way to just get back to my spawn. I couldn't just eject the "forbidden knowledge" from my head. What I eventually realised is that I DID want death to have some kind of punishment, I just didn't want it to cause "oh my god, I'm going to lose hours of progress!" kind of panic. The real solution ended up being installing a gravestone mod so I still had to collect my death loot."@floofzykitty5072 May 2025

item.title: Race
item.description: Races are a classification similar to creature type, mainly tailored towards players. They are the various sapient species and beings that inhabit the setting. When creating a character, players typically choose a race to determine their character's physical appearance, unique abilities, cultural background, and narrative possibilities.Most races have a racial language, but also know common. All creatures are assumed to have a base speed of 30ft, know Common, and be Medium in Size unless otherwise stated.The lore used to describe races is to differentiate a given race from the others. Figment, Subtle
Illusion
An illusory duplicate of yourself leaves your square, which moves at up to your Speed per round and takes a path of your choosing. It can go around corners if you know where to turn to not hit terrain or creatures. It cannot replicate any actions besides moving and smiling.
Creatures that are threatening you when you cast this spell must make an AoO on the duplicate (Will negates).If the duplicate enters a creature's space or impassable terrain, any creature that witnesses it instantly disbelieves it. A creature that identifies your spell when you cast it instantly disbelieves it.

item.title: Tongues
item.description:
Tier 1 Enthrallment Spell
Passive
DivinationYou can understand all spoken non-secret languages. Has no effect on written text. When you speak, other creatures can understand you, even if you don't speak the same language.

item.title: Enthrallment
item.description: Mentalism spells focus on deceit, as well as mental domination of both overt and subtle varieties.Most of this spell list was created by studying the abilities of Shira, a fiend lord Kitsune who stole Free Will from the world for her personal amusement. She is a master of subterfuge, and often exists among mortals, playing along with the politics and wars for fun. Being the least abrasive and the most approachable, Shira is the fiend lord the most mortals find intertwined in their life, often not knowing that they deal with a fiend. Over an enormous period of time, new fields of natural magic formed to fill in the void left by Free Will, such as a Vampire's ability to make thralls. Part of the spell list is sourced from the natural abilities of such creatures.

item.title: Flame Foil
item.description:
Tier 1 Pyromancy Spell
Instant Action, Recharge
Fire
Evocation
As part of taking a Block action against a Melee Attack, such as with a shield, set the attacker Ablaze.

item.title: Self-Immolation
item.description:
Tier 1 Pyromancy Spell
Swift Action, At-Will
Fire, Buff, Persistent, Dismissible
Evocation
You spontaneously combust, taking 4 Fire Damage at the end of each turn. Whenever a creature is adjacent to you, it takes 4 Fire Damage.
You gain +5 Speed.
Upcast 1 - +2 Damage, +5 Speed.

item.title: Flame Surge
item.description:
Tier 1 Pyromancy Spell
Action-Attack, At-Will
Fire, Concentration
Evocation
You begin firing a constant stream of fire at a target. At the end of their turns, they take SP+CL Fire Damage and count as being Ablaze until the end of their next turn for the purposes of effects that call for it (it does not add additional damage). If they leave the range at any point, the spell ends.
Upcast 2 - Can target one additional creature.

item.title: Ablaze
item.description: When a creature is set Ablaze, it takes 2d8 Fire Damage at the end of each turn and suffers -2 AC. Before taking damage, it gets a Reflex save to end the effect. A creature can choose to inflict Knockdown on itself at the end of its turn for a +4 bonus to this save.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Ablaze.md

item.title: Pyromancy
item.description: Pyromancy is magic centered on setting the world on fire, prioritizing mass destruction over anything else. Its realm of study focuses on volcanoes, wildfires, and monsters of flaming origin.

item.title: Dimensional Anchor
item.description:
Tier 2 Academy Spell
Action-Attack, Recharge
Abnegation
You fire a tangled web of green energy as a ranged attack, causing the creature struck to become Dimensionally Anchored.

item.title: Feather Fall
item.description:
Tier 1 Academy Spell
Immediate Action, Recharge
EvocationUsed to save people from deadly falls. The willing target gently falls 60 ft per round until they land safely on the ground, taking no fall damage. The spell ends when they touch the ground, or after one minute.
Upcast 1 - Target an additional creature.

item.title: Mage's Weapon
item.description:
Tier 1 Academy Spell
Action-Attack, Limited
ConjurationYou create a magical piece of basic weaponry, such as a dagger or mace, or a basic shield. It deals Magic damage in addition to its original type.

item.title: Magic Claw
item.description:
Tier 1 Academy Spell
Action-Attack, At-Will
Evocation
Target takes SP Magic Damage on a failed save.
Upcast 1 - Add Spell Power to damage.

item.title: Raging Blow
item.description:
Tier 1 Savagery Technique
Action-Attack, Recharge
Make a melee Attack. On hit, Shove your target and add distance equal to your damage (rounded down to the nearest 5).Upcast 1 - Add d8 Damage.

item.title: Shove
item.description: Push the target 10ft away from you. On Crit, add an additional 10ft.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Shove.md

item.title: Combat Maneuver
item.description:
Combat Maneuvers are Action-Attack that target AC. AC should have separate notes for bonuses towards specific maneuvers. You add both STR and DEX to these attacks, rather than just DEX. When making a Combat Maneuver, you must decide which specific form it takes, such as a Fell, Dirty Trick, or Shove. A successful Combat Maneuver will inflict a condition based on the form you chose. Combat Maneuvers can sometimes benefit from rolling a Critical Hit, by augmenting its power instead of its damage.See:
Dirty Trick
Disarm
Drag
Feint
Fell
Grab
Shove
Steal
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Combat Maneuver.md

item.title: Orc
item.description: The race that's big, mean, and full of green.

item.title: Human
item.description: The most common race, powered by the flames of ambition.

item.title: Half-Link
item.description: The umbrella Race for all animal-humanoid races. Every Half-Link lineage has a distinct and rich culture and history, but every possible iteration is not represented. This version represents the most common, culturally fragmented sets of lineages not otherwise represented.

item.title: Pickpocket
item.description: As a Standard Action, use Trained Hands on a distracted or Surprised creature to pilfer an object off of their person. This is opposed to the Perception of the target and any nearby creatures that can witness you. Failure indicates that the target noticed an unwanted intrusion on their person, and the theft fails. Items that are closely bound to the target cause a -5 penalty to Pickpocket. Items that are worn or held in the hands cannot be pickpocketed.

item.title: XP
item.description: Experience is a meta-currency gained through prioritizing primary campaign events that allows players to influence the story/chronological order of things in order to accomplish personal goals quickly and get back into the action faster. As a baseline, 10 XP is the equivalent of one in-game day of events. Experience is rewarded for spending time working towards campaign goals in an active manner. This mainly means exploring dungeons, splitting heads, and overthrowing governments - anything that is both related to the main campaign objectives, and is not part of downtime events (such as recovering from an Affliction or Crafting). XP is rewarded based on the time required to complete the mission, with additional bonuses for overcoming particular challenges. The purpose of XP is to reward taking action. While downtime is an important part of roleplay, it's easy to justify staying in town making safe money or doing side quests to save up for a shiny new weapon or achieve personal goals if there isn't an obvious time constraint on important story events. It's easy to hold off on an important event and try to squeeze a few more days of crafting into your schedule. Instead, XP serves to reward taking action immediately, without penalizing downtime events like crafting.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/XP.md

item.title: INT
item.description:
Intelligence (INT): Your knowledge, magical expertise, and logic capacity. You add INT to SP
You gain an additional Technique Point.
You gain an additional Skill Proficiency per point of INT
You gain two additional Languages per point of INT (listed in the Skills section under Linguistics) Negative INT subtracts from Spell Power You lose a Skill Proficiency per negative INT
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Ability Scores/INT.md

item.title: CHA
item.description:
Charisma (CHA): Your leadership and personal magnetism. Positive charisma enhances your Companion creatures. Any creature that takes a companion slot gains your CHA to their Accuracy and Avoidability.
For every point of CHA, you can grant another creature one of your Feats. You must Rest with them to do this. They must meet the requirements. You lose a companion slot with negative CHA. Negative CHA reduces your companion's Accuracy and Avoidability.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Ability Scores/CHA.md

item.title: Medicine
item.description:
WIS or INT-based Skill.
Used for Assess Vitality, Provide First Aid, Long Term Care, Prevent Recovery, and Identify Affliction or Curse.

item.title: Martial Artist
item.description:
Masters of mind and body that perform incredible feats of talent and willpower with their weaponized bodies through grit, asceticism, or flashy techniques.1 - TechniquesYou gain 1 Technique point at level 1, then another point every 2 levels after. These technique points can be used on any martial tree.
You gain full progression in Warfare and Unarmed.1 - Flurry
Action-Attack Techniques used with Unarmed Attacks gain +1 AS.
Unarmed Attacks gain +1 AS and deal d4 Damage rather than 1.1 - Core Strength
While wearing Light or no Armor and not using a Shield, you gain +5 Speed/LV and +6 AC vs Combat Maneuvers.

item.title: Class
item.description:
Classes are the fundamental basis from which you obtain abilities.Classes get a set of numerical bonuses to aid them. Every class has listed HP, Skills, Mana, and at least one Save bonus. Stats can be flat front-loaded amounts, per-LV bonuses, or both.
Most characters will get their core abilities front-loaded at level 1. All classes get access to some type of Techniques, which can be martial techniques or spells. Technique points granted through class usually have some form of restriction.Even levels are mostly dedicated to class features that directly increase the classes power. This includes gaining access to new combat abilities, increasing the power of old ones, and getting their own special attacks.
Odd levels are mostly dedicated to getting the next tier of techniques. As such, class features are usually sparse. If any are included, they are usually minor increases in power or they are flavorful inclusions. You also get a Feat every odd level.
Most classes require selecting an Archetype at level 1, which grants more specific thematic abilities.

item.title: Athletics
item.description:
STR-based Skill, or DEX when appropriate.
If you are Proficient in Athletics, you add STR to Jump in addition to DEX.
Used for Climb, Swim, Brute Force, Catch Fall, and Aquatic Combat.

item.title: Jump
item.description:
Jump in a straight line. This can only be used in combination with other forms of movement such as walking or charging.Jump is also a statistic. By default, your Jump is 5. This is a measure of distance, specifically for horizontal jumps, while vertical jumps are half. This does not give you additional movement, and the thus it is limited by your Speed, unless your Jump is higher than your Speed (in which case it functions as your total movement limit when jumping). It can be used to avoid Difficult Terrain, but not if you're already in the Difficult Terrain.
You can only jump once with this action. If you Dash, you can jump twice. These jumps do not need to be consecutive.
Jump distance increases by 5 ft per point of DEX (and STR with Athletics).
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Swift Actions/Jump.md

item.title: Placeholder
item.description: This section needs to be complete.

item.title: Taunted
item.description: A Taunted creature must use all their attacks on the target of the taunt, and must include the target in all of their special attacks (Spells, Su, etc.). A taunted creature can only move if the movement puts them closer to the creature that taunted it.A creature taunted by 2 or more creatures may decide which they'd like to attack (assuming they attack at all).More extreme forms of taunt may restrict the types of actions the creature can take while taunted.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Taunted.md

item.title: Archetype
item.description: A Class Archetype is a specific branch of thematic abilities that are added to the original class. Unless otherwise stated, nothing is lost or replaced by selecting an Archetype.

item.title: Minion
item.description: Minion is a Circumstantial label assigned to a creature as it relates to another. A creature that is 1/3 of the level of another or lower is a Minion compared to it.A level 0 creature is always considered a Minion to any creature of a higher level.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Minion.md

item.title: Template, Class
item.description: Description1 - TechniquesYou gain full progression in Scoundrel and Warfare.1 - Ability1 - Passive

item.title: DR
item.description:
Damage Reduction (DR) is a rare form of defense that reduces incoming damage by a flat amount, noted as a value (DR x). If not specified, DR applies to physical damage, and DRA applies to all Damage types. All DR stacks.
Stacking defenses works in the way that protects the most - such as applying DR after Resistance. If an effect's damage is reduced to 0 with DR, then any associated non-damaging effects are negated.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/DR.md

item.title: Temp HP
item.description: Temporary Hitpoints (Temp HP) are gained separately from your HP. They are lost before your HP, and multiple sources do not stack - only the highest applies.Unless otherwise stated, Temp HP only lasts 1 minute.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Hitpoints/Temp HP.md

item.title: Invocation
item.description:
INT- or LUK-based Skill.
Used for Trigger Magic Device and Ritual.

item.title: Maneuver Adept
item.description:
Combat Feat
You get +4 ACC with Combat Maneuvers, and they can be used as a regular Attack instead of an Action-Attack. This means you can replace an AoO or other simple attack with a Combat Maneuver.

item.title: Spellbreaker
item.description:
Combat Feat
Requirement: Arcana Proficiency
When striking a creature that is currently holding Concentration on a spell with a melee Attack, they must make a Fortitude save or stop concentrating.
A Ranged Attack can be used as well, but the target gets a +4 bonus to their save.

item.title: Ghost Buster
item.description:
Combat Feat
Requirement: Religion Proficiency
You treat Incorporeal creatures as though they were corporeal.

item.title: Fleet Footwork
item.description:
Combat Feat
Requirement: +1 DEX
Increase your base speed by 5ft.
Your movement is Elusive against any target you have hit with a melee Attack this turn.

item.title: Dimensional Reflexes
item.description:
Combat Feat
When a creature Teleports, it Provokes from you.
You get +20 Crit Range with these AoOs.

item.title: Fearsome Finisher
item.description:
Combat Feat
Requirement: Intimidation Proficiency
Whenever you Defeat a creature, you can use Demoralize as an Instant Action, and you get +4 Intimidation for the rest of the combat.
When using Demoralize in this way, you Frighten the target for one round in addition to the normal effects.

item.title: Stat Feat
item.description:
A Stat Feat grants numerical bonuses, such as to Skills or ACC, usually unconditionally, and not much else.
These are for rounding out weaknesses and giving an indecisive PC or DM an easy pick-me.

item.title: Fan Club
item.description:
Combat Feat
Requirement: +1 CHA, LV 3You use your influence and charm to gain a group of people that appreciate you. They are often willing to perform minor tasks for you, stick their neck out for you, but not risk their life for you. They are located in one specific place at first, but they may branch as you gain more levels and influence.
The size of your fan club is CHA((LV)^2).
One member of your fan club is your biggest fan. Your biggest fan is always a Minion. Other than that, there are no restrictions for what your biggest fan can be. When you gain this feat, you decide their class, race, stats etc. They count as a companion if they travel with you.Your biggest fan doesn't necessarily need to be a playable race, but those that aren't should be acquired through story related encounters rather than chosen.

item.title: Elemental Adept
item.description:
Combat Feat
Choose an element from the magical Damage types.
You ignore Resistance against this element. Immunity becomes Resistance.Whenever you wield this element, there is something visually distinct about it versus the norm, such as your flames turning black.

item.title: Quickstep
item.description:
Combat Feat
Requirements: +2 DEX
You can reduce your speeds to 10 to make your movement elusive.

item.title: Endurance
item.description:
Combat Feat
Requirement: +1 STR
The first time you would be Defeated or outright killed in a day, you are instead not Defeated. If it was a result of taking damage, your HP is set to 1.
Whenever you are Defeated, you can make a single attack immediately before you are Defeated.
You automatically pass the STR Roll when Recovering from Defeat.

item.title: Dwarf
item.description: The most relatable Race.

item.title: Defeat
item.description:
When a creature falls to 0 HP, they gain the Defeated condition. They cannot do anything more than a mild whisper while at or below 0 HP. If they are healed to positive hit points, they do not lose the Defeated condition, but they may Crawl at a rate of 10 feet per turn, or move at full speed when assisted by another creature.This mostly only applies to important characters. A character is important when the players or DM say so (often the player characters themselves, an NPC relevant to the story, or a major villain). When an important character defeats an unimportant character, it is assumed they are killed outright unless otherwise stated by the characters attacking.If a creature reaches an amount of negative HP equal to its maximum HP, it dies outright regardless of its importance.
See Recovering from Defeat.

item.title: Defeated
item.description: A Defeated creature cannot do anything more than a mild whisper while at or below 0 HP. If they are at or are healed to positive hit points, they do not lose the Defeated condition, but they may crawl at a rate of 10 feet per turn, or move at full speed when another creature uses Aid. See Defeat.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Defeated.md

item.title: Longshot
item.description:
Combat Feat
At the start of your turn, you can reduce your speed to 0 to remove the penalty from making a Ranged Attack with the second Range increment for this round.

item.title: Combat Reflexes
item.description:
Combat Feat
You can draw a weapon as part of an AoO if you have a free hand.
Gain two additional AoOs. Opponents can tell you continue to threaten past the first AoO.

item.title: Clustered Blows
item.description:
Combat Feat
When you attack the same creature multiple times on your turn, apply DR only once.

item.title: Bonded Weapons
item.description:
Combat Feat
Gain the ability to perform a 10 minute ritual that allows you to bond with 2 specific weapons.
You cannot be Disarmed of these weapons.
When you throw these weapons, they automatically Teleport to your hand after the attack is resolved, if desired.
If these weapons somehow manage to leave your possession otherwise, you can spend a swift action to have them Teleport to your hand.

item.title: Bodyguard
item.description:
Combat Feat
When an ally is moved out of your natural reach (via its own volition or not), you can move as an Instant Action so that it is again in your natural reach.
Any movement you take using this feat counts against your movement for this round. If you cannot reach your ally, you can move as close as you can get. You can position yourself in the most advantageous way around your ally, assuming you have the movement.

item.title: Blind Fight
item.description:
Combat Feat
You are not Surprised while Blinded. You ignore Concealment AC bonuses.

item.title: Back to the Wall
item.description:
Combat Feat
You cannot be flanked as long as you are adjacent to a wall.You are considered flanking a creature that is adjacent to a wall.

item.title: Antagonize
item.description:
Combat Feat
Use Intimidation or Deception to Demoralize a creature. Instead of being Shaken, they are Taunted for one round.
You can extend the duration by using your Swift Action on consecutive turns.

item.title: Range
item.description: Weapons with ranged capabilities (thrown or otherwise) will also have a listed range. Ranges come in an X/Y format, with the X range increment being the accurate range, and the Y being second range increment, taking a -4 penalty.

item.title: Mana Donation
item.description:
By going to specialized facilities, or by going to churches with gilded altars, an untrained creature can donate Mana via Mana Burn. A creature can safely donate up to one less than their maximum. There are usually safeguards against donating your max mana, but less savory individuals don't mind. Spending your max mana gives you the Tier 3 Affliction Mana Starvation. This means that most common people are only able to donate 1 Mana each day. Children typically do not possess enough mana to safely donate.Specialized facilities and gilded altars are incredibly expensive, typically costing hundreds of thousands of gold to craft. This makes it so facilities for mana donation tend to be rather sparse, only located in sizable settlements with magical and religious influence.
When mana is extracted, it is turned into a Mana Crystal. Mana Crystals are versatile and can change between states of matter, becoming either liquid or solid for ease of storage. Each point of mana can earn 4g in a mana extraction facility. In a church, it earns 5 GBP and food/lodging for the day.Most religious services happen in the evening after work, so that way people may spend their mana as they wish during the day, and donate it at night if they wish. With large generous populations this can mean that you can amass large quantities of mana rather quickly. Because most people can only donate 1 mana, you can almost 1:1 translate a population of donors to daily mana generation. Not everybody who donates has commoner tier mana, but at the same time, not everybody can always donate! So the 1:1 ratio is generally the go-to method of determining mana generation over time.Again, not all places have the correct facilities, so this is often available in villages.

item.title: Mana Burn
item.description: Mana Burn is the loss of a daily Mana slot such that it cannot be recovered until you take a Long Rest, and needing to re-prepare the ability to another slot to use it again. This is usually voluntary, but can also be the result of an offensive effect.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Recharging Abilities/Mana Burn.md

item.title: Mana
item.description:
Mana Slots (Mana): All creatures have 2+LV Mana unless otherwise stated.
When selecting Techniques or Spell, each one takes up one Mana Slot, unless otherwise stated.
How you use a given slot is determined by whether the ability is At-Will, Recharge, or Limited. At-Will abilities can be used as you like, without affecting the Mana Slot.
Recharge abilities will temporarily consume the slot until you use the Recharge Abilities action. You do not need to re-prepare the ability, it returns to the slot as if it was not spent once you use the recharge action.
Limited abilities will make you lose the slot until you Long Rest. This is sometimes referred to as Mana Burn. You can re-prepare the ability to assign it to a different slot and continue to use it.
When you learn abilities that must be assigned to a slot, you must Rest to assign them to those slots. A given ability can only be assigned once in your loadout. You can rest again to reassign your abilities.Abilities gained through class features or items usually do not take up Mana Slots, and thus you cannot re-prepare your ability to a different slot if it's Limited.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Recharging Abilities/Mana.md

item.title: Populations
item.description: Settlements receive classifications based on population. More populous settlements tend to condense more wealth, have more facilities and are more cosmopolitan. Expensive or luxurious services can be expected in larger settlements, but are unheard of in smaller ones.Hamlet - <1,000 peopleVillage - 1,000+ peopleCity - 10,000+ peopleMetropolis - 100k+ peopleSome general assumptions about a given population: About 10% of the population is assumed to be over level 0, with a skew towards early levels. Most regions have a dominant religion, with at around half the population favoring them. Metropolises tend to have more variety, while hamlets tend to be entirely dominated by a single religion.

item.title: Ritual
item.description: Rituals are complicated and time-consuming projects that use a large amount of materials and Mana to produce a powerful effect far beyond the strength of an individual spell. It is similar to Crafting.

item.title: Trigger Magic Device
item.description: Use Invocation to try and trigger the effects of a magical device without meeting the requirements for its use, such as bypassing a password, activating an item you're not qualified to use, or activating a sigil that only works in the presence of another type of creature. You have no control over the effect once it's active. Failing this check often comes with unforeseen consequences.

item.title: Perform
item.description:
CHA-based Skill.Proficiency in Perform only applies to specific instruments or Performance types. The bonus for having this skill only applies to the chosen types. Examples of Performances include instruments like flutes, pianos, or drums, physical displays such as singing and dancing, and displays of charm such as comedy.
Used for Performance and Economics.

item.title: Identify Magic Item
item.description: Use Arcana to identify all of the magic properties of a Magic Item in reach as a Standard Action. The DC is the item's Potency, +10 if it's cursed.This can be attempted once per day per item.

item.title: Charmed
item.description: Creature cannot attack the entity that inflicted this condition. The entity that inflicted this condition has a +4 bonus on Charisma Skills against this creature.This ends if the creature that inflicted the condition harms the charmed creature.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Charmed.md

item.title: AoO
item.description: Attack of Opportunity (AoO): An Instant Action Attack triggered in response to certain actions of others. All creatures can do this once per round by default. When a creature "Provokes," they are engaging in an action that allows others to AoO them.Movement can only provoke once from a given creature per turn.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/AoO.md

item.title: Attack
item.description:
Attack rolls are any type of harmful effect targeting a creature that does not require a saving throw. This can be spells, swords, or trying to push your foe off of a cliff (see Combat Maneuvers).Default: Roll+ACC+/-(circumstantial bonuses or penalties)
When you roll an attack, you compare it to the target's AC. If you roll under it, you miss, and you usually deal no damage. If you meet it, you hit, and roll the damage associated with the attack. If you roll 20 or more points over their Avoid, you Critically Strike (Crit), adding your Critical Damage to the attack.

item.title: Burrow
item.description:
Burrow Speeds allow Movement through dirt, clay, and other particulate turf, but not solid rocks (unless otherwise stated). Burrowing leaves a temporary hole the size of the creature that burrowed for a few rounds, depending on the sediment type, unless the creature takes measures to avoid this.
Starting to burrow is a Swift Action that Provokes as if leaving a Threatened space.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Movement/Burrow.md

item.title: Fly
item.description:
Fly Speeds allow Movement in any direction. They may remain in the air as long as they have a Fly Speed - Flying targets get +4 AC against Ranged Attacks while flying.
A creature that is Entangled or Grounded cannot continue flight.
A creature that takes damage from an Attack or AoE effect while flying receives Clumsy 1 until they land, up to 6 stacks.
Starting to fly is a Swift Action that Provokes as if leaving a Threatened space.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Movement/Fly.md

item.title: Hover
item.description:
Hover Speeds allow Movement above solid and liquid surfaces while ignoring Difficult Terrain. They may remain in the air as long as they have a Fly Speed - Flying targets get +4 AC against Ranged Attacks while flying.
A creature that is Entangled or Grounded cannot continue flight.
A creature that takes damage from an Attack or AoE effect while flying receives Clumsy 1 until they land, up to 6 stacks.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Movement/Hover.md

item.title: Difficult Terrain
item.description: Difficult Terrain is a Circumstance that represents reduced movement due to physical blockage. This can be because of wading through knee-deep mud, flying through dense brush, or burrowing through particularly rocky turf.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Movement/Difficult Terrain.md

item.title: Clumsy
item.description: Creature takes a stacking penalty to Reflex and AC equal to the Clumsy value. This otherwise functions like Shaken. A Clumsy creature cannot ascend using Flight, or things that function similarly to flight, such as a Hover Speed.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Clumsy.md

item.title: Pack Tactics
item.description:
Teamwork Feat
Flanking only requires threatening the same enemy, regardless of position.

item.title: Flanking
item.description: Flanking is a Circumstance that grants +2 ACC against a target that you and an ally are Threatening from opposite sides.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Flanking.md

item.title: Tandem Charge
item.description:
Teamwork Feat
Requirement - Move As One
During an ally's turn, if they make a Charge Attack, you can spend an Immediate Action to charge along with them and make a simple attack. You must charge attack the same creature they do.
Your Speed is zero on your next turn.
Turn based games make movement awkward, but the idea is you are moving together, so other positional effects, such as Escape Route or Shield Brothers, can treat moving allies as within reach for the duration of the movement in circumstances where allies converge on a location or start in positions that are close to each other.

item.title: Move As One
item.description:
Teamwork Feat
During an ally's turn, if they move, you can spend an Immediate Action to use your movement to move along with them. You must either end this movement within their natural reach, or threatening the same enemy as them.You subtract this movement from your movement next turn.
Turn based games make movement awkward, but the idea is you are moving together, so other positional effects, such as Escape Route or Shield Brothers, can treat moving allies as within reach for the duration of the movement in circumstances where allies converge on a location or start in positions that are close to each other.

item.title: Shield Brothers
item.description:
Teamwork Feat
Gain +2 AC when you are within the natural reach of an ally that wields a shield. The shield must have an AC bonus. You can use any shield benefit on an ally instead of yourself, as long as they remain within your reach.

item.title: Escape Route
item.description:
Teamwork Feat
Movement out of threatened squares also threatened by your allies is elusive.

item.title: Teamwork Feat
item.description: A Teamwork Feat is a Feat that provides a benefit only if used with other creatures that have the same feat.

item.title: Feat
item.description:
Feats are class features in progression that are gained every odd level. They allow your character to get bonuses to specific actions, abilities from other classes, and occasionally get general stat increases.
Some feats have prerequisites, such as stat requirements, Skill Proficiency, or other feats. You must meet all of the requirements of a feat to take it.

item.title: Dodge Roll
item.description:
Tier 1 Deceit Technique
Immediate Action, Recharge
Elusive
After getting attacked, gain +4 Avoid against the attack, and move 10 feet in a straight line.

item.title: Weakness
item.description: Having a Weakness means you take 50% more damage from Damage of that type, or have a -4 penalty to Saves against effects of a certain type if they are not damage.

item.title: Immunity
item.description: Having an Immunity represents that a particular Damage type or classification of ability has no effect on you.

item.title: Resistance
item.description: Having Resistance to a Damage type makes you take half damage from it.

item.title: Psychic
item.description: Psychic is a Damage type Tag, representing an assault one a creature's mind. Usually ineffective against Mindless creatures.

item.title: Necrotic
item.description: Necrotic is a Damage type Tag, representing the decay of flesh, poisons, and the organic disruption of life processes. May bolster Undead.

item.title: Holy
item.description: Holy is a Damage type Tag, representing attacks against the soul or convictions, or divinely-sourced retribution. Usually particularly effective against Undead and Fiends.

item.title: Cold
item.description: Cold is a Damage type Tag, representing the disruption of movement and natural processes through cold and freezing.

item.title: Fire
item.description: Fire is a Damage type Tag, representing destruction through heat melting metal or cooking flesh.

item.title: Lightning
item.description: Lightning is a Damage type Tag, which represents ionization and burning through the use of electricity.

item.title: Crush
item.description: Crush is a Damage type Tag, which represents bludgeoning attacks, shockwaves, and blunt force trauma.

item.title: Magic
item.description: Magic is a Damage type Tag, which represents damage that is supernatural in origin, forces rending and unmaking through means that cannot be described by physical processes.

item.title: Slash
item.description: Slash is a Damage type Tag, and represents damage dealt by cuts, chops, and slices with a sharp or thin weapon.

item.title: Pierce
item.description: Pierce is a Damage type Tag, and represents force applied across a small surface area, usually by pointed objects.

item.title: Undead
item.description: Undead are souls wearing flesh that no longer lives, powered by foul magic that binds spirits into servitude beyond death. Respect for the dead in many cultures comes from experience of what happens when the dead are desecrated, as lynching, mass murders, fires, and other horrific deaths where the death is not properly honored can result in the creation of naturally-occurring undead.Undead created naturally typically have unfinished business, obsessions, or grudges against those that wronged them. They are often lucid of the facts surrounding their demise, and do everything in their power to correct their qualms - after which they must be put to rest.Undead created by outside forces are constantly suffering a cruel fate, forced to live in broken bodies and without a will of their own. Casters that engage in this magic must be wary, as every day that passes runs the risk of letting the latent memories in these spirits manifest into wills of their own with their only desire being to destroy the caster that enslaved them. In the same vein, a caster that respects the wishes of a created undead can use their unfinished desires to their advantage, using alliances over enslavement to form lasting bonds until they are put to rest.

item.title: Extraplanar
item.description: An Extraplanar creature is any creature that originates and lives in another plane of existence. It cannot be found in the universe unless it came through a portal from another dimension, or it was summoned.

item.title: Celestial
item.description: Celestials are the creatures from higher planes, all which serve a specific purpose towards furthering the order of the universe. They range from Angels, divine messengers of holy gods that aid in the fights against chaos, to Inevitables, single-minded beings that enforce the laws of the universe and root out those that try to break them. Creatures in this group tend to respect and bargain with others in the same group, as they all have similar goals. An Angel may bargain with Death to reincarnate a necessary ally, or consult with an Inevitable to learn of how to stop a reality-warping ritual. All Celestials are Extraplanar.

item.title: Yokai
item.description: Yokai are a category of Fiends. Consistent, exceptionally evil acts from the most heinous and powerful individuals and organizations can cause the creation of legendary fiends that become forces of nature themselves. These events strip away the identities of those that propagated them and their victims, burning away their souls before their time is up, and leaving them with no desires except for the game itself.

item.title: Fiend
item.description: Fiends are chaos incarnate. They seek to destroy the natural order in any way they can, usually by killing, burning, and corrupting everything that exists until there is nothing but suffering and ruination left.Many come from lower planes, such as devils and demons that form from the recycled souls of deceased mortals. These fiends are made from pure malice, making them almost impossible to trust or convert. There is no humanity left in them, all that remains being used only to trick and outsmart mortals. They often reflect the worst of the humanoid races, as traits that are normally considered sinful become manifest in their abilities. Luckily for the material plane, most extraplanar fiends need assistance or coordination to escape The Abyss from which the come.Despite this never-ending blasphemous source, many of the most powerful Fiends often come from the material plane itself, known as Yokai.

item.title: Beast
item.description: The Beast group contains a wide variety of mundane animals, ranging from nimble rodents and cunning predators to massive herbivores and resilient scavengers. Whether encountered in dense forests, treacherous mountains, or bustling urban areas, these beasts are simplistic and feral, reminding players of the wilderness's unpredictable nature and the survival instinct that drives all living things.Beasts are mostly unintelligent one-trick ponies, and are quick to flee when their trick fails, or when their opponent proves more dangerous than their value in meat. Herbivorous beasts typically only fight in self-defense, and will flee unnecessary battles.

item.title: Fey
item.description: Fey are whimsical nature-bound creatures that live on the border between fantasy and reality. Many appear dreamlike or nightmarish, or like the results of hallucinations, often with nonsensical anatomy and far too many colors.Fey tend to serve mundane, but otherwise natural purposes in the world, such as the spread or cleansing of disease. Some represent concepts or ideas that are otherwise neutral, such as fey of happiness, sadness, marriage, censorship, and flavor.Fey cultures often appear whimsical and mischievous, contrasting sharply with the more straightforward attitudes and behaviors of humanoid cultures.

item.title: Plant
item.description: Plant creatures are made of plant matter. This group also encompasses Fungi. This group ranges from towering treants to carnivorous vines to networks of mycelium, but typically show off a high degree of symbiosis and adaptation to their environment and local creatures. It is often difficult to tell friend from foe apart in this group, as an unidentified pod could just as easily be a source of food as it could be a lure into a pit of thorny vines.

item.title: Construct
item.description: Constructs encompass all constructed beings, ranging from ancient golems animated by arcane forces to intricate automatons powered by sophisticated machinery. Most constructs are created by an intelligent mind, but some are formed from natural primal magic. Their purpose can vary greatly, most serving as simple guards or weapons, while technological or intelligent constructs may be made to write, convey information, and research.Most constructs tend to have a "master" when made, or a method of establishing control over it. Their minds tend to work like programs, working entirely within the scope of their directives, or with a single-minded purpose - however, autonomous, free-thinking constructs are not unheard of.

item.title: Titan
item.description: Titans are enormous, long-lived and usually ancient creatures similar to Humanoids. They are almost always intelligent, and often have their own societies and cultures. This is the realm of giants and mythical beasts of incredible proportions.

item.title: Humanoid
item.description: Humanoids represent the humanoid races, as well as anything sufficiently humanoid to use the same weapons and armor that a human does. They tend towards using tools, techniques, and teamwork to defeat their enemies, rather than natural attacks or abilities.

item.title: Abomination
item.description: Abominations are terrors born from the unknowable and the otherworldly. They cannot be reasoned with. They are utterly insurmountable nightmares that humanity has no hope of escaping.From the darkest depths of space, the ocean and other mysterious realms, aberrations are often alien creatures uninterested in the conventions of traditional life. Others are strange mixes of the organic and inorganic in unfamiliar animalistic shapes.Abominations are characterized by organized domination, horrific departures from traditional violence, hiveminds, and eerie motives.

item.title: Ooze
item.description: Oozemorphs are amorphous creatures that are biological in nature. Despite their apparent homogeneity, they are equipped with many of the same faculties as other living creatures, such as membranes, means of digestion, and ways to detect and react to stimuli. They are usually mindless, taking on the roles of dangerous traps and hazards to catch and devour unsuspecting victims. Intelligent Oozes are more active, often using their durability and physical properties to overwhelm their victims.

item.title: Monster
item.description: Monsters are a magical and significantly more intelligent step up from otherwise mundane creature types. They are rare mythical creatures, larger than life and saturated with power, ranging from the inescapable Minotaur to the mighty Dragon. They almost always come with incredible magic powers, such as deadly breath weapons, teleportation, and even illusions.

item.title: Monster Quality
item.description: Monster Qualities are abilities, such as techniques or senses, that are most common on non-player creatures.This is a list of common special abilities and their descriptions, used to save space on bestiary entries.

item.title: Bestiary
item.description: The Bestiary is a collection of creatures that populate the world, usually as fighting threats. The bestiary is separated into 2 sections: Monster Qualities and the monsters themselves. Monster Qualities are not always exclusive to bestiary creatures, but are much more common on them. Many qualities that appear frequently are not described in bestiary entries and are instead described there in order to save time/space.

item.title: Pick Lock
item.description:
Use Hands to open a lock without a key.
This takes 1 or 5 rounds, depending on the DC of the lock - DC 30 and up is 5 rounds.
Attempting this without a Thief Tools gives a -5 penalty.

item.title: Dismissible
item.description:
Dismissible (D) effects can be ended prematurely by the caster as a Standard Action.
Note that voluntary effects (such as buffs) can be dismissed Instantly without this tag.

item.title: Emotion
item.description: An Emotion effect is a Mind-Affecting effect that relies on manipulating the target's emotions.

item.title: Confused
item.description: Creature considers all others enemies. Every turn, they roll d10+LUK to determine how they act. For confusion effects that last more than 1 round, each subsequent d10 roll gets 2 added to the result.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Confused.md

item.title: Su
item.description: Supernatural abilities encompass any ability that is magical, but not a Spell.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Su.md

item.title: Lighten Object
item.description:
Tier 1 Academy Spell
Standard Action, Limited
TransmutationThe target object or willing creature's weight is reduced by 100 or by half, whichever is less.
Upcast 1 - The weight can be reduced by an additional 50.

item.title: Levitate
item.description:
Tier 1 Academy Spell
Standard Action, At-Will
Concentration, Air
EvocationYou move an object or willing creature 5 ft through the air every round. The target cannot use movement while it's benefiting from this spell.

item.title: Magic Guard
item.description:
Tier 1 Academy Spell
Instant Action, At-Will
Abnegation
You redirect a portion of incoming damage to your Mana.
When you cast this spell, you reduce an incoming instance of damage by (SP+ CL).
This consumes one of your Mana Slots. You may sacrifice other prepared abilities to fuel this spell, or this ability (though if you sacrifice this one, you can't use it again until you prepare it again).

item.title: SP
item.description:
Many Spell and similar abilities have their variable effects based on Spell Power.
Spell Power is decided by your Staff of choice (usually d6) plus your INT.Spells often include Spell Power in their total damage. When they do, they may also add Spell Power when Upcast.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/SP.md

item.title: CL
item.description: Spells often include Caster Level as part of their total damage, or they may use it in calculating opposed checks, such as when dispelling.By default, your CL is equal to your LV, and your spell's CL is equal to yours plus any bonuses you have to it, such as from Staves.Usually, the term refers to the effect's CL itself, not the user's personal CL. Usually, a creature's personal CL does not deviate from their level much, if at all. Therefore, assume any use of CL does not refer to personal CL unless otherwise noted.

item.title: Scholar's Hand
item.description:
Tier 1 Academy Spell
Standard Action, At-Will
Concentration, M (Focus): Writing Utensil, Parchment, Paper
ConjurationThis spell has two uses, the first of which does not require the focus component.
You create a translucent hand that can pick up items and perform simple tasks, such as opening doors, pulling up pants, or tipping over buckets. It can carry up to 10 lbs and has a +0 bonus to Athletics. The hand can continue to act independent of you as long as you concentrate.The hand can also write as you do, and can be used to write in or copy a book used as a focus, at a rate of about one page per minute.

item.title: M
item.description: Any spell with a Material Component has an item with a price associated with that is consumed on use. Anything with a Focus component has an item with a price associated that is NOT consumed on use.You do not need to have these items in your hand - they merely need to be on your person to be used. They may briefly appear in the visuals of the spell or otherwise float out of your inventory as necessary.

item.title: Academy
item.description: Spell Technique Tree.In the heart of every large city, the scholars and the wealthy gather around places of magical research to stay relevant in a competitive and difficult world of magic. These places focus on imparting general knowledge of best practices and methodologies to their students, a basis from which they can further the research and development in their field of magic. Those who choose to immerse themselves in the Academy skill tree embark on a journey of rigorous study and practical mastery, gaining a profound understanding of the skills and self-defense techniques needed to take on the occult world beyond the city walls.

item.title: Kidnap
item.description:
Tier 1 Deceit Technique
Action-Attack, AS 2, Recharge
Make a Drag attempt with a +4 bonus. If successful, Dash as a Free Action.
Upcast 1 - Increase bonus by 2.

item.title: Single Out
item.description:
Tier 1 Deceit Technique
Action-Attack, At-Will
Make a melee Attack. If the target is not within 15 ft of one of its allies, it takes an additional d8 damage.
Upcast 1 - +d8 damage.

item.title: Pocket Sand
item.description:
Tier 1 Deceit Technique
Action-Attack, Recharge

Upcast 1 - +2 ACC.

Tier 1 Deceit Technique

Elusive
Move to the opposite side of a creature and make a melee Attack against it. It is Surprised against this attack.

item.title: Deceit
item.description: Technique Tree.Abilities that spit in the face of chivalry, using underhanded techniques and finding unusual information to win against the odds.

item.title: Revenge
item.description:
Tier 2 Savagery Technique
Immediate Action, Recharge
This ability is used in response to being hit by an Attack of Opportunity. Make a melee Attack against the creature.

item.title: Foe Throw
item.description:
Tier 1 Savagery Technique
Action-Attack AS 2, Recharge
Throw a creature you are grabbing at another. Both take 2d10 damage and fall Prone. The target gets a Reflex save to negate the effect. The thrown creature ends in an adjacent empty space closest to you. You do not need to target a second creature with this ability; you can choose to target any space. This counts as a weapon with the Thrown property.
Upcast 1 - Damage increases by d10.

item.title: Gore Paint
item.description:
Tier 1 Savagery Technique
Passive
BuffYou are covered in blood, sludge, entrails, ectoplasm, or other entrails as you fight.
After defeating an enemy, or while at or below 10 HP, gain +15 Speed and +d10 Critical Damage.

item.title: Second Wind
item.description:
Tier 1 Warfare Technique
Full-Round Action, Limited
Healing
You very briefly tend to yourself and focus, giving yourself half your HP in Temporary HP, up to your total missing HP. This Provokes until the start of your next turn.If used on an ally, you both must take the action, and you both Provoke.
This bonus HP lasts until you roll Initiative again.

item.title: Bloodlust
item.description:
Tier 1 Savagery Technique
Immediate Action, Recharge
Healing
After landing a melee Attack, gain half of the damage as Temp HP.

item.title: Callout
item.description:
Tier 1 Warfare Technique
Immediate Action, Recharge
BuffYou have a watchful eye of the actions around you, and you shout to your allies to warn them.
When an ally Attacks, you can grant them +2 Accuracy after the roll. When an ally is attacked, you can grant them +2 Avoid after the roll.You cannot use this on yourself.
Upcast 1 - The bonus increases by 1.

item.title: Quickdraw
item.description:
Tier 1 Warfare Technique
Instant Action, RechargeYou are able to change your equipment as if it was the start of your turn.

item.title: Ground Pound
item.description:
Tier 1 Savagery Technique

You take the Jump action as part of this technique. Upon landing, adjacent enemies become Clumsy 1.
Upcast 2 - Increase Clumsy penalty by 1.

item.title: Warfare
item.description: Technique Tree.In a realm where conflict is an inevitable aspect of existence, Warfare represents the mastery of strategic combat techniques developed throughout a long history of war. This tree is designed for those who understand that warfare is not only about brute strength but also about cunning planning, decisive leadership, and the ability to adapt in the face of adversity. Whether leading a small skirmish or marching through a sea of fire, practitioners of this skill tree will become adept at turning the chaos of the battlefield into a calculated display of tactical prowess.

item.title: Taunt

Tier 1 Warfare Technique

Fear

Upcast 1 - Gain an additional +2 ACC.

item.title: Critical Damage
item.description:
Critical Damage: Damage added to a Crit.
By default, this amount is d10+LUK damage. This is in addition to your attack's normal damage.
This only applies to HP damage, and does not add to any other effect. Items and abilities may change your Critical Damage.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Critical Damage.md

item.title: Surprised
item.description:
Creature is unable to respond effectively to attacks due to Stealth, Feinting, or some other status or Circumstance. Attacks made against a Surprised creature get a +10 bonus.This status effect is also a Circumstance that can be determined on a per-creature or per-attack basis, but can also be a condition that applies to all incoming attacks.
Creatures Surprised by the start of a combat also place below non-Surprised creatures regardless of Initiative result.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Surprised.md

item.title: Size and Reach
item.description: This game is meant to be played on a grid of hexes or squares. Personally, I prefer hexes. Creatures must be represented in such a space. That's why creatures are broken up into size categories.Creatures threaten all spaces they occupy by default.You can enter the space of a creature that is a size category larger or smaller than you. If you leave a space occupied by a creature, it provokes an AoO as though you were leaving a threatened area. If you get attacked this way, the same creature can't also AoO you for leaving their threatened square in the same turn.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/More Rules/Size and Reach.md

item.title: Perception
item.description:
WIS-based Skill. All creatures are Proficient in Perception, unless they are Mindless or specify otherwise.
Used for Detect. Used as a defense against skills like Hands and Stealth.

item.title: Silenced
item.description: Creature cannot speak, including to cast Spell.Spells that state an absence of speech can still be cast.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Silenced.md

item.title: Swift Action
item.description:
Swift Action: This action can be executed during any other action, with a limit of one per turn. See: Hide
Jump
Use Potion
Recharge Abilities
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Swift Action.md

item.title: Identify Potion
item.description: Use Alchemy to identify a held Use Potion or Poison with a sniff or taste. The DC is the item's Craft DC.

item.title: Weather and Terrain vs Spells
item.description:
Certain high level spells manipulate the weather or terrain in drastic ways. If multiple casters attempt to cast different spells that affect the same weather, the higher CL always wins.
In the event where the caster tries to interfere with weather that is supernaturally powerful (created by natural magic, associated with cursed terrain, etc.), the DM should assign the effect an effective CL.All weather-inducing spells do not function underground.With smaller-scale terrain changes or unforeseen interactions between spells and an environment, an opposed CL check is more appropriate.
item.guid: Techniques/Spellcasting Rules/Weather and Terrain vs Spells.md

item.description: SP

item.title: S
item.description:
All spells have a Staff (S) Component. Disarming a mage of their staff prevents them from casting using it, and ends any spell they're concentrating on with it."Staff" components do not need to be exclusively provided by staves. Many other items, such as wands and seals, can also be used to serve the Staff component.
Staff - Staves are usually long and sturdy pieces of wood. Most of the magical components of the staff are attached to the end of it. Staves can universally be used as weapons, and may augment specific kinds of spells.
Seal - Seals have an enormous amount of variety to them. They are typically compact: Some small handheld object, often of spiritual significance. Seals are ineffective unless they are the only thing occupying the hand. Seals often alter the use of spells.
Wand - Wands are usually small pieces of wood about in the rough shape of a pencil, but usually a bit larger. Wands are lightweight and easy to bring many of, and may grant additional spells prepared.
Tome - Tomes, grimoires, or otherwise magical books can often serve as Staff components. They can be used to prepare spells you do not know, and must be in hand when used to cast said spells.

item.title: Staff
item.description: A staff is a subtype Weapon Group. This is also a label used for anything that can complete the Staff (S) component of spells.
item.guid: Equipment/Weapon Rules/Weapon Types and Basic Weapons/Subtypes/Staff.md

item.title: V
item.description: All spells have a verbal component. Verbal components cannot be whispered, and you must speak them clearly. Anything that prevents the mage from speaking prevents them from casting, such as being silenced.The verbal components often contain a plain-language reading of the spell's structure or its name, in a Language known by the caster. When observing a caster using a language you understand, you need only have Arcana to identify it.

item.title: Technique
item.description:
A Technique is the form most abilities take. They are one of the major means of combat progression in the game. Techniques are often things that you use in combat, but many have out-of-combat uses as well. Spells may contain a greater portion of out-of-combat effects.Techniques are either martial or magic, in the form of Spells. By default, non-Spell Techniques are Martial. In general, classes get access to a few technique trees. They gain technique points at odd levels, or may automatically get a specific tree at those odd levels. Techniques are separated into five levels, requiring 6 points of investment in order to reach the highest tier.Every even level, you get a technique point you can invest into any technique path, separate from what you get from your class. For every point you invest, you get access to a new level of technique.
Technique levels have a hard character LV requirement when investing points to unlock more. At level 1, you can unlock the first tier, but every tier thereafter is available at every odd level, maxing out at tier 6 at level 11.

item.description: Description

item.title: Property
item.description: Mundane Item. Property is synonymous with land, and everything on it. Property can include facilities, homes, or resources of interest. The price of property changes based on a few factors, such as size, buildings, appearance, location, and the overall state its in, to name a few.

item.title: Tools
item.description: 80g Mundane ItemTools typically come in sets catered to a specific task, such as fishing or medicine. Some tasks require the use of tools, others only give a penalty if you don't have tools.Tools also come in a masterwork variety, giving the user a +4 bonus on the skill in question. The price is increased to 800g.Some tasks do not have associated tools, and therefore are not suitable for acquiring masterwork variants to them. Skills like medicine, alchemy and profession use tools. Skills like stealth, perception and persuasion do not. Some types of tools might be able to aid you with novel types of tasks, such as using a spyglass to roll perception long distances, but should not give any types of persistent flat bonuses.Most tool kits weigh 10 lbs. Some tasks, such as smithing, require even more advanced tools you can't carry around, such as a forge.

item.title: Torch
item.description: 10g Mundane ItemTorches are sticks wrapped with some type of cloth, chemical or vegetable matter that is flammable. Torches give off bright light in a 20 ft radius around them, and dim light 20 ft past that.They can stay lit for up to 2 hours. Lighting and dimming a torch repeatedly can significantly decrease the amount of time they stay lit.If a torch ends up getting wet, it becomes unusable.

item.title: Mundane Item
item.description: Mundane Items can usually be bought in many locations around the world with the correct vendor in town. Many have real life analogues.

item.title: Wanderer
item.description:
You go wherever the road takes you. You might have had a home once, but for one reason or another you had to or wanted to leave.You start play with a standard rock. More information can be found in the bestiary. Very basically, rocks are autonomous mass transportation and shipping vehicles. Most significant places in civilization will have service stations and parking available.
See Backgrounds

item.title: Tradesman
item.description:
You worked in a job that required a specialized form of training, such as an alchemist, a doctor or a blacksmith. Over the years of your work you have accumulated a few tools of the trade.Select one of the following presets, or make one that's similar. Regardless of the selected trade, you have a place of work that you can return to that views you favorably, has masterwork equipment available for use, and that you can get +10% Wealth from through related sales and deals.
Doctor - You start off with a medicine kit, a dose of troll oil, and 3 doses of Bloodblock.
Alchemist - Start off with an alchemist kit, a love potion, and 2 alchemist fires.Craftsman (weapons/armor) - Start off with a set of combat ready equipment. You can start off with
Heavy armor and a weapon
Medium armor, 3 melee weapons, a ranged weapon, and a shield Light armor, 6 light melee weapons, 2 ranged weapons, and a shield
See Backgrounds

item.title: Noble
item.description: You come from an upper ring of society. Your name might not carry the same weight everywhere you go, but your gold pouch certainly does.You get a bonus 1,000 starting gold that you can spend as you wish. Your family also gives you an allowance every month of 500g. For campaigns with a faster or slower pace, such as if there are frequent time skips, consider changing how often the allowance comes in.If you are far from home, it can take up to a week for your allowance to arrive. They can only ever be picked up from settlements.See Backgrounds

item.title: Family Man
item.description: You are the primary owner of a house somewhere in the world, usually at least on the tangent of civilization. You lived with either your immediate family, like parents and siblings, or you made a family of your own with a spouse and children.You own a meager house in a specific place, and a handful of family members to come home to after an adventure. Your house is always considered a suitable place to rest in order to cure general afflictions.See Backgrounds

item.title: Background
item.description: Background helps to determine what your character was doing before they got sucked up into an adventure. Other than acquiring the skills necessary to go out into the dangerous world, of course.Backgrounds give starting bonuses or equipment.

item.title: Weapon
item.description:
Weapons are the most basic method of increasing one's offensive power. Just having a weapon and attacking an enemy is often enough to make you a substantial threat, regardless of your expertise or abilities.Weapons fall into Weapon Groups for the purpose of identifying what Special Attacks, Abilities, and Techniques they're compatible with. The categories describe how they are used to attack, rather than how they look. If a weapon has more than one main category, then that means its category changes based on the way it is used, such as throwing a dagger instead of swinging it.There are ten main categories:And 4 subtypes:
Exotic Weapons do not neatly fit into these categories, and will list how they differ.Weapons come with damage values, attack speed values, and damage types as their core stats, in addition to the categories listed above.
All standard weapons deal a physical Damage type. If a weapon has more than one damage type, you can decide which to use before you make a given attack with it.
Damage values and Attack Speed correlate such that the damage tends to be very similar without any additional abilities or STR. The typical offense-oriented damage values and AS are as follows:
Weapons with ranged capabilities (thrown or otherwise) will also have a listed range. Ranges come in an X/Y format, with the X range being the accurate range, and the Y taking a -4 penalty, referred to as the Range.
Some weapons come with Techniques and Special Attacks. These temporarily grant you a technique as long as you wield them. As per the Mana rules, you cannot sacrifice your own Mana to get another use of a Limited Technique unless otherwise stated. Special Attacks specifically are also tied to the weapon - If you use the Special Attack, you cannot pass the weapon off to another creature to use it again, and the weapon has its own Recharge timer.
Many weapons come with Weapon Qualities. These describe what a weapon does beyond its classification, Damage, and AS.Unless otherwise stated, Weapons weights default to the following:

item.title: Stealth
item.description:
DEX-based Skill.
Used for Hide and Hide Trail.

item.title: Recharge
item.description: A Recharge ability can only be used once, after which you can use the Recharge Abilities action to restore it.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Recharging Abilities/Recharge.md

item.title: Hands
item.description: DEX-based Skill.Used for Pickpocket, Conceal Item, Pick Lock, and Disable Device.

item.title: Profession
item.description:
WIS or INT-based Skill. For crafting, INT is used, and Trained individuals can use any ability score for Economy uses if doing so has a justification in-character.Professions can be anything used to provide a service or create a product. When you gain a profession, you choose one such specialization, such as Profession (Baker).
Used for Economics and Quiz.

item.title: Survival
item.description: WIS-based Skill.Used for Navigate, Butcher, Live off Land, and Track.

item.title: Coax
item.description:
When an NPC is on the fence or indifferent about a request, and the requester doesn't have anything left to say to sway them, Persuasion can be used to get the target to agree or counter-offer.
The DC varies based on how effective the conversation was before rolling. Requests that align with the target's interests, offerings that make them happy, and moral arguments that resonate with their values will lower the DC, while the opposite will increase it. Passing the check results in the NPC requesting something in return, while rolling significantly higher may cause them to waive any additional requests, or even offer additional assistance that wasn't requested. This action can also be used when the NPC already agreed due to good conversation in-character, in order to try to sweeten the deal if the requester rolls exceptionally well.

item.title: Humanities
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Humanoids and Titans.
Used for Recall Customs, Recognize Figure, and Recall Locale.

item.title: Religion
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Undead.
Used for Divine Lore.

item.title: Planes
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Fiends, Celestials, and Elementals.
Used for Detect Portal.

item.title: Nature
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Plants, Fey, and Beasts.
Used for Identify Natural Phenomenon and Identify Spell.

item.title: Knowledge
item.description:
INT-based Skill. You cannot roll Knowledge if you are not Trained.
Knowledge is broken up into many different skills based on subject, and each one has a subsection dedicated to Monster Lore of specific types of creatures. Monster Lore isnât its own skill, it is instead an action that uses the individual Knowledge skills. If a subject or creature falls into multiple categories, then players can choose whichever they like more, but an individual character can't roll multiple checks with different skills - instead, they receive a +2 bonus for each overlapping Knowledge they possess.
If you want to know who an individual creature is and their relevance to the world, rather than their stats and abilities, the DC is usually dependent on how popular they are. This is typically 30-LV with additional reductions to the DC if they are famous or in a position of power, or increases in the DC if they work to keep their identity and exploits hidden.
All Knowledge Skills can be used to recall the History of the associated subject as well, such as using Humanities to learn about ancient Elf-Human relations that shaped the current world.

item.title: Engineering
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Constructs.
Used for Identify Function, Hack, and Identify Structural Quirk.

item.title: Arcana
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Monsters.
Used for Identify Spell and Identify Magic Item.

item.title: Astronomy
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Abominations.
Used for Navigation, Identify Spell, and Identify Cosmic Phenomenon.

item.title: Alchemy
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Oozes.
Used for Identify Potion, Identify Composition, and Craft alchemical items.

item.title: Intimidation
item.description:
CHA-based Skill, or optionally STR when using displays of might.
Used for Coercion and Demoralize.

item.title: Insight
item.description:
WIS-based Skill, but CHA can be used if it's a social cue.
Used for Detect Dishonesty, Detect Compulsion, and Intuition.

item.title: Deception
item.description:
CHA-based Skill, normally rolled against Insight.
