By using Trained Insight, you can observe a structure or item whose function is known, an event unfolding, or a behavior pattern to try and glean information about it. The DC is modified by how much knowledge you already possess on the topic, or how closely you're able to investigate it. A success gives you nearly prescient knowledge about the intention behind the structure, item, event, or behavioral pattern that goes beyond a basic understanding of function.
For example, when used on a Trap whose function is to shoot an arrow, your character may determine that based on its unusual angle and obvious placement, it may have been used to deter adventures from finding a secret in its line of sight instead of to actually effectively trap them. The knowledge you glean from this success will always be the reality of the situation when you follow your intuition.

item.title: Disguise
item.description: Using Trained Deception, spend 10 minutes perfecting your makeup, outfit, and wig to appear as a person or playable race you're not. Disguise checks are usually unnecessary unless you fall under scrutiny, the person knows you/what you're pretending to be, or you're trying to enter an exclusive club, in which case they get a Perception check. Creatures get bonuses to their Perception if they know you or what you're disguised as particularly well.You take a -2 penalty to Disguise when you try to change your race and when you change your apparent gender. When you initiate a Disguise, you tell your DM your bonus, they apply any appropriate Circumstance modifiers and roll it in secret.Crafting a disguise without a disguise kit or magic imposes a -5 penalty.

item.title: Detect Compulsion
item.description: Use Trained Insight to determine when a creature is under duress from a spell or some other kind of effect that has a lasting impact on their mind, such as when Dominated or Possessed. You must actively search for this by speaking with the creature for 1 minute. Roll Insight vs the DC of the effect. If the effect has no DC, assume a basic DC based on the Potency of the source.

item.title: Lie
item.description:
Use Deception against a target's Insight to speak falsehoods, or to soften the truth. See Detect Dishonesty. It may be more entertaining if the DM rolls this in secret to preserve tension.
Common modifiers to increase the DC include: The target has firsthand experience with the events Claims that are fantastical or impossible, such as equating angels with demons or asserting a green sky The target is knowledgeable of the subject matter Common modifiers to make the task less difficult can include: The target is inattentive, such as from being tired or drunk The target trusts you

item.title: Detect Dishonesty
item.description:
Whenever a creature makes a statement, you can roll Insight (opposed by Deception) to see if what they say aligns with what they think. If you roll lower, or if they aren't being dishonest, you don't detect dishonesty. If you succeed, you determine that something is fishy - or if a statement lacks nuance (such as a yes or no response), you can determine the correct answer. Prying further about the deception may cause the creature to reveal the truth or become hostile depending on context.
This can be combined with Deception against their Insight to hide whether or not they know you know they're being dishonest. When this is done, it may be more entertaining to have the DM roll in secret, and distribute results in secret, in order to preserve tension.You can only roll Insight on a particular assertion or topic once.

item.title: Coercion
item.description:
With Trained Intimidation, by having a conversation with a creature that lasts at least one minute, or by defeating a creature in combat, you can shape how they respond to you or anybody asking about you in the future. The strength of this creature's conviction is dependent on your Intimidation Roll against it.
You can make the creature keep their mouth shut about something you did to them. Any checks to gather information from this creature about you or your party change to your roll if it would be higher than the usual DC.
You can greatly exaggerate what you did to further spread fear and grand tales of your strength. Any Knowledge checks that creatures make on you when hearing about information that spreads from this creature changes to your Intimidation roll if it would be higher than the usual DC, or else they learn false information.

item.title: Demoralize
item.description:
As an Action-Attack, inflict Shaken 1 on an enemy that can see or hear you within 30 feet. Roll Intimidation versus their Will. They are Shaken as long as you are nearby, and for 1 minute after. You can Demoralize a creature repeatedly to increase the penalty. If they pass their save, their shaken value from Demoralize decreases by 1.
If you are Trained, you can inflict Frightened instead on creatures you have Defeated before. This lasts one round, and can only be done once per day per creature. This doesn't work if they Defeated you once before as well.

item.title: Sucker Punch
item.description: If you are in some kind of standoff where you aren't quite fighting your enemy yet, you can use Trained Deception or Trained Hands as a replacement for Stealth to Surprise your enemy with a melee Attack. The enemy must be aware of you in order to Sucker Punch, otherwise it is Stealth, and you must already be adjacent to use Hands for it. If you don't use an Unarmed Strike, then you have disadvantage on this check, unless you use Hands.Certain situations where you are not able to get close to your aggressors, such as having bows pointed at you from a garrison above you, make Sucker Punching impossible.

item.title: Subtle Message
item.description: By speaking in roundabout terms and making subtle gestures, you can use Trained Deception to communicate a simple idea (such as "we need to leave", or "time to strike") while not talking about it directly, to avoid alerting others of your intentions. The DC to convey this message is 20. The intended recipient automatically understands the message. Anyone that may be suspicious gets an Insight check to beat your Deception.

item.title: Tie
item.description: When making an opposed Skill check, ties are rerolled.

item.title: Create a Distraction
item.description: Using Deception as a Standard Action, you can shout something at your enemies to briefly get them to look the other way so you can give them the slip. All creatures get a roll to try and beat yours. If you succeed, you are able to roll Stealth, and they won't know where you went. This does not prevent people from finding you again using Perception.

item.title: Submerged
item.description: Target is completely surrounded in liquid. This triggers Aquatic Combat and Improved Cover.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Submerged.md

item.title: Improved Cover
item.description:
Improved Cover is an environmental Circumstance that increases your AC and Reflex by 8.
Improved Cover is received against Ranged Attacks and AoEs that target you while there are obstacles between you and the source of the attack that obscure almost all of your space, usually intentionally designed to allow attacks only in one direction, and that cannot be pierced by the attack.
Examples include arrow slits and murder holes., as well as ranged weapon attacks against Submerged targets.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Cover/Improved Cover.md

item.title: Knocked Down
item.description: Creature is temporarily Prone until the start of the inflicting creature or effect's next turn, at which point the condition ends without Provoking or spending Movement, unless the creature is Held Down.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Knocked Down.md

item.title: Held Down
item.description: Creature cannot stand from Prone.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Held Down.md

item.title: Prone
item.description: Creature is lying down or otherwise on the ground, has -4 AC and ACC, and can't move unless they spend 30 movement to end the condition, which Provokes.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Prone.md

item.title: Ability Scores
item.description:
These are representations of a creature's innate or cultivated affinities. These represent the mind, body, and spirit. The ability scores are Strength, Dexterity, Luck, Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma.
Every Player Character gets 3 points to increase their ability scores as they wish, starting from 0 in each.You can decrease a single ability score to -1 in order to gain an additional point. The maximum points you can invest in a given ability score is 2.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Ability Scores/Ability Scores.md

item.title: Group Checks
item.description: When working cooperatively, such as to Craft an item or work a machine, use the group's highest bonus, plus 1 per helper, or 2 if they're also Proficient (max +10). When the weakest link can sink a team's effort, such as with Stealth, use the group's lowest bonus, plus the help.

item.title: Take 10
item.description: You can take 10 on non-opposed skill checks. This means instead of rolling, you automatically get a Natural 10. This is suitable for crafting or skipping tasks that aren't too difficult for you.

item.title: Proficiency
item.description: Proficiency in a Skill marks you as "Trained" rather than "Untrained." Proficiency grants more uses for some skills.

item.title: Critical Pet
item.description: Achievement Requirement - Use stealth to initiate combat on a creature by patting its head 3 times. This pat can have no mechanical effect such as delivering a spell or attacking.Reward - You unlock the "Pet" skill. It uses your stealth bonus. If you sneak up on a creature and pet their head (again, no additional mechanical effect), you establish dominance, giving you a +2 bonus to skills for the subsequent social or combat encounter. If a creature within reach is smaller than you, you can pet them as a free action 1/turn for no mechanical benefit (no save).

item.title: Battle Scars
item.description: Achievement Requirement - Get defeated by a critical hit and survive in 3 different encounters. Or get crit 3 times in the same combat and survive.Reward - The scars you get from battle are deeply entrenched in your memory. Your memories of combats you have encountered cannot be magically removed. By touching them, you can perfectly recall past events, as long as they happened in the thick of combat. Other creatures can touch your scars to share in the experience of the memory

item.title: Backstabber
item.description: Achievement Requirement - Murder 3 people you once considered allies, or who at thought you were an ally (before you turned on them). If you murder someone in a position of great power, like a powerful guild leader or king, it counts as 3.Reward - You have a 6th sense for when people trust you. By observing how they react to your presence in a brief interaction (such as an introduction), you can tell whether they trust you, are indifferent towards you or if they distrust you.

item.title: Progression Outside of Class
item.description:
Boons/Banes - Gained at level one as a result of having positive or negative luck.
Feats - Gained at level 1, and every odd level after.
Technique Points - Gain one that can be used on any school of techniques at level 2, and every even level after.
Achievement - Can be gained at any time, even retroactively, when certain conditions are met, varying based on the achievement.

item.title: Achievement
item.description: Achievements are archetypal tasks that provide some kind of tangible benefit after completion. You do not need to opt into an achievement, instead they can be claimed retroactively after accomplishing a task.

item.title: Line of Effect
item.description: A straight line between two places with no Total Cover or impassable obstacles for a given effect grants Line of Effect. This is different from sight, as you may be able to see someone and not Target them (such as through a window).
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Line of Effect.md

item.title: Targeted
item.description: A Targeted ability refers to one where you must select targets to apply the effect, which is not an Attack Roll. Some abilities are particular about what they work on, and will fail if used outside of their scope. You must have Line of Effect and be able to see your target to target them. If you cannot see them, you must target their space with the intention of targeting them.

item.title: Total Cover
item.description:
Total Cover is an environmental Circumstance that makes you Untargetable.
Total Cover is received against Ranged Attacks, AoEs, and Targeted Abilities that target you while there are obstacles between you and the source of the attack that leave no way to reach you, and that cannot be pierced by the attack (in the case of Ranged Attacks and Area Effects.)
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Cover/Total Cover.md

item.title: Movement
item.description: You can move up to your Speed on your turn. Some abilities or effects may require spending a certain amount of your movement for the turn. Abilities that move you do not cost or consume any of your movement unless otherwise stated.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Movement/Movement.md

item.title: Dazed
item.description: A more severe version of Staggered. Creature cannot take a Standard Action and cannot make AoOs. -15 Speed.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Dazed.md

item.title: Staggered
item.description: Creature can only take a Standard Action or Swift Action each turn, not both. -15 Speed.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Staggered.md

item.title: Chilled
item.description: Creature is covered in ice. Creature has -2 AC, Resistance to Fire Damage and -15 Speed. This status ends when they take physical or fire damage.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Chilled.md

item.title: Action System
item.description:
This game is played turn-based, with turn order determined at the start of the battle with an Initiative roll. The actions you can take on your turn are as follows. Standard Action: This action occupies most of your turn, and you can perform one per turn. Example: The Attack Action is the most common, allowing a series of smaller attacks up to your Attack Speed, executed in any order. Refer to the "Attack" section for more details.
Swift Action: This action can be executed during any other action, with a limit of one per turn.
Free Action: These actions are effortless or part of other actions, allowing you to perform as many as you wish per turn - within reason.
Full-Round Action: This action requires the use of your standard action and all of your free Movement. You may still move if you have an ability that allows extra movement as a different action. When it's not your turn, you can take the following actions:
Immediate Action: A Swift Action that can occur off-turn. Limited to one per round, shared with Swift Action â you cannot use both in the same round.
Instant Action: A Free Action that can occur off-turn. Referred to as "Instantly" in abilities.
Attack of Opportunity: A response triggered by certain actions of others. Limited to one per round. When a creature "Provokes," they are engaging in an action that allows others to AoO them.
Movement: You can move up to your Speed on your turn. Some abilities or effects may require spending a certain amount of your movement for the turn. You may have other forms of movement that manifest in terms of different Speeds - you may use multiple forms of movement on the same turn, but only up to the maximum amount for the given speed. Any slower speeds used overlap - That is, if you have a Fly 40 and a ground speed of 30, you may walk 30 feet and then fly another 10.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Action System.md

item.title: Disarm
item.description: Knock a held item out of a creatureâs hand, landing at their feet. It takes 30 ft of Movement or a Standard Action to pick up an item off the ground, which Provokes.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Disarm.md

item.title: Feint
item.description: Feint is the use of Deception vs the target's Insight. Feint is NOT considered an Attack, but you can still use your ACC in place of Deception. It is still classified as a Combat Maneuver, and can benefit from any bonuses or defenses relevant to them.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Feint.md

item.title: Steal
item.description:
You take an item that is not in the target's hands, but is otherwise accessible on their person. Steal can use Hands in place of ACC.
Worn Equipment is assumed to be ineligible targets unless it is an Accessory.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Steal.md

item.title: Character Creation
item.description: There are several things for you to decide when deciding what you're writing down on your character sheet. Start with a theme, aesthetic, fighting style, or a particular character type you want to mimic from popular media.These are in order of necessity for actually playing the game, but not necessarily in the order that is most convenient to any individual's workflow.

item.title: Fortitude
item.description:
Fortitude Saves are one of the three primary Saves Rolled to avoid a negative effect.
Your Fortitude represents your resistance to physical hardship, such as Poison, Disease, and concussive attacks.
You add STR and LV to your Fortitude, as well as any bonuses from your Class.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Saving Throws/Fortitude.md

item.title: Reflex
item.description:
Reflex Saves are one of the three primary Saves Rolled to avoid a negative effect.
Your Reflex represents your reactions and ability to evade or mitigate sudden attacks such as Area Effects and Traps.
You add DEX and LV to your Reflex, as well as any bonuses from your Class.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Saving Throws/Reflex.md

item.title: Will
item.description:
Will Saves are one of the three primary Saves Rolled to avoid a negative effect.
Your Will represents your mental resilience and ability to resist mental attacks such as Illusions, mind control, and Fear.
You add WIS and LV to your Will, as well as any bonuses from your Class.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Saving Throws/Will.md

item.title: Carry Weight
item.description: A creature's Carry Weight represents what it is capable of lifting and moving around with without much effort.The default value is 100, but some factors may change this.A creature can lift and drag twice as much as their carry weight, but is staggered while doing so.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Ability Scores/Carry Weight.md

item.title: Alternative Win Conditions
item.description:
For when killing everything that moves isn't what you want, alternative win conditions seek to answer the question of "How do I end combat without reducing the enemy hp to 0?"See: Restraint
Surrender and Morale
Truce
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Alternative Win Conditions/Alternative Win Conditions.md

item.title: Instant Action
item.description: Instant Action: A Free Action that can occur off-turn. Referred to as "Instantly" in abilities.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Instant Action.md

item.title: Standard Action
item.description:
Standard Action: This action occupies most of your turn, and you can perform one per turn. Example: The Attack Action is the most common, allowing a series of smaller attacks up to your Attack Speed, executed in any order. Refer to the "Attack" section for more details. See: Administer Potion
Aid
Attack Action
Carry
Charge
Dash
Disengage
Prepare
Total Defense
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Standard Action.md

item.title: Rolling Dice and Statistics
item.description: This game relies on a special roll, detailed below. It will be referred to as dX in the content.Action resolution is done by using random chance to represent a range of success in an attempt to reach a target number, combined with a bonus based on your character's build, such as from their ability scores, skills, class features, active buffs, and feats.Content is currently being made with a roll equivalent to counting successes on a d15 die, exploding on any number above 1, success being any roll (including the first). This can be written into rolling simulator websites such as Roll20 to speed things up.The benefit of this method is that anyone can roll any number, unlike other systems where a large enough target number will make the roll impossible.The Short Version: Every point added for or against these rolls is about a 7% difference in power. This means Attack Rolls, Skill checks, Saving Throws, DCs, Avoid, all of it. A 6 point difference is roughly a 50% boost in odds. A 10 point difference is about double. As an example, if you gain 10 Accuracy or 10 Stealth, your odds of success are about twice as high. This is the case regardless of the opponent's statistics.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Rolling Dice and Statistics.md

item.title: Polymorph
item.description: Polymorph effects transform creatures into other creatures. Many of the features granted from polymorph effects are based off the Shapeshifter's class features. You retain the ability to speak while polymorphed. When transforming using a polymorph effect, it can fall under one of the following to determine the nature of your transformation (some can be multiple).Chimeric Polymorph - Your form stays roughly the same, but acquires some features of the new creature that you're transforming into, such as claws, fur, a long tongue etc. When you chimeric polymorph, you do not lose access to any of your gear.True Polymorph - Your form completely changes to the form mentioned in the ability. You completely lose access to all of your equipment. There are only a handful of features recognizable from your previous self, such as eye color.Baleful Polymorph - This form of polymorph is inflicted upon you rather than willingly used. It functions very similarly to true polymorph, but provides fewer tangible benefits and often include debilitating Status. You lose access to your equipment and cannot speak.

item.title: Death and Resurrection
item.description:
The purpose of resurrection in TTRPGs is primarily for the benefit of the players. If a DM makes frequent use of the resurrection spells for entities that the players went to great lengths to kill, it heavily undermines their effort and feels terrible, even if plausible.The powers that be should instead be very particular about the who gets a second chance. If the players are the main character of the story, then the game's resurrection mechanics should treat them as such. As a replacement for most resurrection effects, use these rules instead. Or don't use resurrection at all. It's your game. Whatever.IMPORTANT NOTE: Please make sure your players are on board with whatever you decide. Nobody likes surprise mechanics.See: Ashen One
Cloning Device
Limited Resurrection
Tombstone
Withers
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Death and Resurrection/Death and Resurrection.md

item.title: AoE
item.description: Stands for "Area of Effect." It is used as shorthand to describe an attack that affects a wide area, such as an explosion, or a line of fire from a dragon's breath.Area attacks have a point of origin. When the origin is a creature, such as with a breath weapon, determine Cover from one specific point in its occupied space. If the origin is a targeted point in space, such as with an explosion radiating outward, that point should be used to determine cover.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/AoE.md

item.title: Threaten
item.description: The area a creature threatens represents where they can make attacks. This usually only applies to melee attacks. This area also marks where it is typically not safe to perform certain actions, or risk getting hit with an AoO.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Threaten.md

item.title: Limited Resurrection
item.description: Pose a caveat to resurrection magic that imposes a severely limiting factor, such as only being able to revive a creature shortly after it died with some kind of resource attached to it. Maybe even make it a limited resource by tying it to physical items, like scrolls with this effect attached to it.EFFECTDESCRIPTION You breathe new life into a recently deceased creature. If the creature has died within the last minute, they are brought back to life at 1 hp and drained 1.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Death and Resurrection/Limited Resurrection.md

item.title: Light Level
item.description:
Light comes in 3 forms.Bright Light A sunny day or a torch lit room. Bright light let's creatures see things clearly. Most creatures can see in bright light without any penalty.Dim Light Moonlight or at the edge of your torch light. Many humanoids cannot see well in dim light. Features in dim light appear only as a silhouette with dull, if any, color. Without special senses, creatures have Partial Concealment in dim light.
Darkness The depths of a cave or deep underwater. Few creatures can see clearly in a complete darkness. Some, such as humans, can't see at all. Those that can (such as with night vision or Darkvision) still only see in grayscale. Without special senses, creatures have Total Concealment in darkness.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/More Rules/Light Level.md

item.title: Fall Damage
item.description:
Fall damage increases by 3 Crush for every 10 feet you fall, capped at 60 damage. Every 50 feet you are also Drained 1, capped at 4.When determining fall distance, subtract your Jump.
If you fall further than your AC (Trip), you are Knocked Down.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/More Rules/Fall Damage.md

item.title: Stacking Damage and Defense
item.description: When you stack a source of flat damage reduction and multiplicative reduction, add them together in the way that reduces the damage the most.When you have multiple sources of increasing damage by a percentage, add the percentages together, do not multiply.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/More Rules/Stacking Damage and Defense.md

item.title: Rounding Numbers
item.description: Always round decimals down, minimum 1.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/More Rules/Rounding Numbers.md

item.title: Truce
item.description: In situations where there are two opposing sides that are generally neutral towards each other or even allies with each other, you can call for a truce. This generally requires important information (we were sent by the merchants guild), certification from an important or recognizable organization (legal documentation) or a special item (an artifact or flag).It could also be appropriate to call for a truce if you are delving into a dungeon and encounter another party, so long as you aren't after the same thing. You might not cooperate, but at least you won't be killing each other. If more information is revealed by talking throughout a battle (wait you're also hunting for the garbooni?), you can also reasonably call for a truce.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Alternative Win Conditions/Truce.md

item.title: Restraint
item.description:
When creatures don't surrender, but you donât want to risk killing them, restraints can be used to end the fight. Some situations can naturally be neutralized by dropping a cage in the right place, but such conveniences are rare. More often than not, restraining your foe is going to involves rope and cuffs.#CuffsGrabbing and already-grabbed creature allows you to put cuffs on them.One grab is needed per appendage cuffed. You cannot cuff a creature on your own unless you can grab multiple times per turn, in which case you need another free hand. This provokes AoO.This completely prevents the use of their arms outside of simple item interactions. Cuffs can also be placed on the legs to reduce a creatures speed to 15. Combat maneuvers made against a cuffed creature gain a +10 bonus.Cuffs are difficult to escape, and even harder to break. They typically require outside assistance in order to be removed. Because cuffs are typically made from iron and steel, they can take a significant beating.DC to break (Athletics) or lockpick (Hands) is dependent on the type of material and the lock. A typical forged cuff is DC 40 to break, or 20 to pick.Creatures that are bound can try to free themselves, but take a -5 penalty.
#RopeGrabbing and already-grabbed creature allows you to tie them with rope.One grab is needed per appendage tied. You cannot tie up a creature on your own unless you can grab multiple times per turn, in which case you need another free hand. This provokes AoO.Rope is easier to destroy than cuffs, but it is also easier to make the restraint more intense. By grabbing one more time, you can prevent the creature from acting completely.Rope tends to be a good way to bind singular creatures, since anybody with a sharp implement can handily free a bound creature.Rope can be destroyed with an attack from any slashing weapon. Using Athletics or Acrobatics, you can pull the ropes apart, but the DC is determined by the athletics bonus of the creature who bound you (30+their athletics bonus). Creatures that are bound can try to free themselves, but take a -5 penalty. This penalty can be ignored with a natural attack suitable for freeing yourself, or a slashing concealed weapon.
#ContainerGrabbing and already-grabbed creature allows you to forcefully shove them into an object within reach such as a bag, barrel, or box, so long as they can handily fit in the object.Whether or not they can escape generally depends on the object and the tools the captured creature has on hand. Wooden crates donât do to well when trying to hold barbarians or crafty characters with crowbars.DC to break (Athletics) is dependent on the type of material. Some objects can be handily dealt with, not requiring a skill check. A knife makes quick work of a bag, and given enough space, hammers break boxes.Creatures that are bound can try to free themselves, but take a -5 penalty.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Alternative Win Conditions/Restraint.md

item.title: Surrender and Morale
item.description: During combat there come times when you do not wish to fight, usually when one side is close to victory, but can also happen when creatures are clearly outnumbered or outmatched.How well a surrender feels in a situation usually comes down to a gut feeling, affected by a lot of variables. In order to even consider a surrender to be viable, one or more of the following (or other applicable) conditions should be metâ¦ Numbers advantage Some other clear advantage, such as terrain, positioning, equipment or a powerful noteworthy ally Heavily damaged or unconscious allies Consequences for not surrendering (often death or further prosecution) Hostages Whether or not creatures are minions or named characters A surrender requires clear communication, which may not always be possible given the hectic and spread out nature of battle. Some creatures, particularly mindless ones, will not surrender unless specific circumstances are met. Creatures of animal intelligence can be convinced to surrender if you can speak to animals or have wild empathy etc.Surrender can mean forfeiting weapons, fleeing in fear, begging for mercy or something similar. If not all individuals accept the surrender, then the fight continues until they do.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Alternative Win Conditions/Surrender and Morale.md

item.title: Ashen One
item.description: In dark souls, certain types of creatures, namely the player character, hold a special place in the world's lore. When you die you don't reload the game, you canonically respawn at the location you last rested, leaving behind all your money where you died.You could choose to adopt a similar system where certain types of conditions need to be met for these unique creatures to die for real. Having the characters lose all their money might not be the best approach for a TTRPG: players like their money. But, in souls games you can go back to the place you died and collect the money again, so maybe.This kind of natural respawn mechanic is a good fit for campaigns where you expect your players to encounter dangerous creatures on the regular and your players don't get too discouraged from losing. Meat grinder without the consequences of losing your character for good.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Death and Resurrection/Ashen One.md

item.title: Withers
item.description: In Baldur's Gate 3, there is an NPC that shows up in your camp that has a vested interest in your success. He has powers that aren't like normal characters, chief among them the ability to resurrect fallen allies. You could easily introduce a similar character into your campaign, maybe even the introduction to the campaign is this NPC resurrecting the players.This particular method has the benefit of being less nebulous than divine forces. It gives someone the players can interact with and someone that can give them direction. Whatever the reason they have for resurrecting your players, it's because they need their help.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Death and Resurrection/Withers.md

item.title: Cloning Device
item.description: You start off your adventures waking up in some alchemist's lab, surrounded in copies of yourself. Whenever you die, there is a fresh body waiting for you back at the lab that your soul gets sucked into.This plays more into having a secret base type thing, and it feels a little less metagame-y than "chosen by god." it also has an interesting mystery component to it. Why were you guys chosen as clones? Whose lab is this? How's that for storytelling with resurrection?
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Death and Resurrection/Cloning Device.md

item.title: Tombstone
item.description: In the event of your characters untimely demise, worry not, for the gods smile upon you. When killed, your body becomes a tombstone with your name and face on it. It weighs as much as you did, including all of your equipment. This tombstone can be carried back somewhere to perform a ritual and bring the character back to life.This can be a place of significance to this god, something generic like a church or something with more story relevance. It can be wherever home base is, or you can require the players to reach certain points in the campaign in order to get their characters resurrected (Ex: Your friend died by the lich's hand, and now, to get them back, you have to destroy his phylactery. Make a temp character!).The basic idea is there: satisfy this entity's conditions and life will be restored.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Death and Resurrection/Tombstone.md

item.title: Teleportation
item.description: Teleportation effects allow the user, and sometimes their allies, to instantly travel between two locations. Teleportation tends to be very limited in scope, bringing you to very specific predetermined places or being wildly off-course if not. If unspecified, you must have line of sight to the location you are teleporting to.

item.title: Sigil
item.description: The effect puts magical text on a surface with some kind of delayed effect, usually triggering when a creature walks within a certain radius of the sigil. A sigil must be clearly visible in order to function. If it is obscured, then it is deactivated until it is unobscured. Most sigils have the ability to apply a passphrase that, when spoken aloud, allows a user to move through the area without triggering the sigil.

item.title: Transmutation
item.description: These spells focus on changing things into other things.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/School Tags/Transmutation.md

item.title: Illusion
item.description: These spells focus on warping perception to impose one's will over others.Enchantment spells are Illusion spells that are also Mind-Affecting.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/School Tags/Illusion.md

item.title: Evocation
item.description: These spells focus on the manipulating elements and focusing power to destructive effect.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/School Tags/Evocation.md

item.title: Divination
item.description: These spells focus on gaining knowledge through spying and querying the universe.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/School Tags/Divination.md

item.title: Conjuration
item.description: These spells focus on summoning, displacement, and temporary creation.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/School Tags/Conjuration.md

item.title: Abnegation
item.description: These spells focus on disabling magic and protection.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/School Tags/Abnegation.md

item.title: Scrying
item.description: Scrying effects create a specific type of magic sensor, often from remote locations, usually for the purpose of spying on people. The sensor allows you to see and hear anything with any of your senses, so long as it is in the specified range the effect mentions.Scrying sensors are clearly visible to the naked eye. They usually take the form of an eye. Sensors that can move can use the caster's stealth bonus to hide as they move.

item.title: Persistent
item.description: Persistent Effects have an initial effect and an effect that persists over time. This type of effect cannot deal its persistent effect on the same round as its initial effect. Persistent effects end preemptively if the user is Defeated.

item.title: Pattern
item.description: Like a Figment, a Pattern creates an image that others can see, but a pattern also affects the minds of those who see it or are caught in it. Common effects include Fascination or Blurred Vision. Pattern effects are also Mind-Affecting.

item.title: Fascinated
item.description: Creature cannot take actions other than watch the source of its fascination. Creature loses this condition after it is attacked, has a Saving Throw inflicted on it, or succeeds on a Perception check to notice a creature in its pockets or otherwise taking an offensive action. If the source of its fascination is no longer visible (or able to be sensed for other types of fascination), the condition also ends. After this happens, the creature temporarily becomes immune to fascination for 1 minute.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Fascinated.md

item.title: Multi-Strike
item.description: This effect, when used with an Action-Attack, is improved by attacking multiple times. It may apply its effect to every attack on your turn.

item.title: Martial
item.description: Martial effects allow the user to deliver the effect using the ACC and Damage and On-Hit Effects of a wielded Weapon, even if it mentions using another form of attack.Martial techniques and Special Attacks by default ALWAYS have the martial tag. It is not listed to save time/space.

item.title: Mindless
item.description: Creature does not have any capacity for reasoning. It performs basic motions regardless of external stimuli.This status grants immunity to many Mind-Affecting effects.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Mindless.md

item.title: Mind-Affecting
item.description: Mind-Affecting effects are a more general group that include things like Fear effects, Charms, and more. Creatures that are Mindless cannot be affected by mind-affecting effects.

item.title: Glamer
item.description: A Glamer changes a subjectâs sensory qualities, making it look, feel, taste, smell, or sound like something else, or nothing at all.

item.title: Figment
item.description: Figments create creatures, objects, and terrain that donât truly exist. As long as the creature does not directly interact with a figment, it believes it to be real. If a creature figures out that it's fake and tells its allies, or demonstrates by moving through it, they no longer believe it to be real. Directly interacting requires doing things like walking into a wall or attacking a creature, upon which the creature rolls a Will save. A failure indicates the creature will try to run around an obstacle or that they missed a creature.If used to satisfy the conditions of a surrender (such as making a spooky monster), the creatures affected get a will save to negate it. They have +6 on this save if they saw you cast the spell.

item.title: Fear
item.description: Usually inflicts Shaken or Frightened. All fear effects are also Mind-Affecting.

item.title: Elusive
item.description: Elusive: This action doesn't provoke an AoO.

item.title: Water
item.description: Effect manipulates water to produce its effect.This is a non-Damage elemental tag.

item.title: Air
item.description: Effect manipulates air to produce its effect.This is a non-Damage elemental tag.

item.title: Earth
item.description: Spell manipulates earth to produce its effect.This is a non-Damage elemental tag.

item.title: Darkness
item.description: Effect either creates darkness, or has special interactions when in it.

item.title: Cursed
item.description: A Cursed creature is suffering from a permanent debilitating condition. Curses cannot be dispelled, but they all have some way to get rid of them. This usually requires some convoluted action most people wouldn't do unless prompted. Can be identified using the "identify curse or affliction" feature in the Medicine skill.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Cursed.md

item.title: Curse
item.description: Curse effects inflict permanent debilitating conditions on creatures. Curses cannot be dispelled, but they all have some way to get rid of them. This usually requires some convoluted action most people wouldn't do unless prompted. Can be identified using the "identify curse or affliction" feature in the Medicine skill.

item.title: Charm
item.description: Charm effects allow the creature inflicting it to exert some degree of control over others. All charm effects are also Mind-Affecting.

item.title: Companion
item.description:
In media it's very common for creatures to have minions, squires and sidekicks. This is what the companion system is for. Like most other content, the companion system is ill-suited for large quantities of creatures, like armies. It's meant to be more compact. Something to take with you on the go for your adventure. This could also reasonably extend to temporary allies that join your party.Companions are generally tied to your class, abilities and items. Any such ability is marked with this tag.If an ability has the companion tag, it summons an ally, or otherwise serves some kind of interpersonal function. You can only have 2 companions, or 1 if you have -1 CHA.
Companions always act on your turn if you are present. There is no separation between your turns, you all act in the same Initiative (rolled by you). Companions gain bonuses or penalties based off of your CHA.

item.title: Concentration
item.description: An effect with the Concentration tag requires some degree of upkeep from the caster and typically has a duration. Concentration effects end if the caster is Defeated, Stunned, put Asleep, or otherwise completely prevented from taking any actions. You can also cease concentration Instantly. If you cast a spell with concentration, you must hold the staff in order to maintain your concentration. Being disarmed of a staff you are using to concentrate ends the effect. While you are concentrating on a spell, you cannot use that staff to cast other spells. However, you can use another staff to cast spells, or concentrate on another.

item.title: Contingent
item.description: The effect can be cast ahead of time with a specific trigger for when it activates. A creature can only have a single contingent effect active on them at once.The effect manifests as a clearly visible wisp of energy that floats around the creature. The DC to identify the effect increases by 5, but the fact that there is a contingent effect is clear.

item.title: Caloric
item.description: Effect either creates Food, or has special interactions when using it.

item.title: Bond
item.description: An effect with the Buff or Bond tag grants a boon to a creature, or a shared effect. If an unwilling creature has a buff or bond used on it, it can choose to deny it.

item.title: Buff
item.description: An effect with the Buff or Bond tag grants a boon to a creature, or a shared effect. If an unwilling creature has a buff or bond used on it, it can choose to deny it.

item.title: Time Out
item.description: A creature in Time Out has lost the will to fight, and has surrendered to you. They cannot inflict harmful effects on anybody or anything. They also cannot cast spells without your permission. They meekly follow your commands (ex. follow me), but wonât do anything against their ethos (kick that puppy) or that is dangerous (jump off that cliff) without extreme circumstances. If you or your allies attack the creature or cast a harmful spell on it, the condition ends.Treat it like a slightly more convenient form of unconsciousness if you want to interact with the creature after the combat. Many minion type creatures will acquire this status effect when their leader is defeated.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Time Out.md

item.title: Stasis
item.description: Creature is frozen in time, or some other particularly powerful effect. They are Untargetable, Unassailable, Unstoppable and Invincible. They cannot take any actions unless otherwise stated.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Stasis.md

item.title: Untargetable
item.description: Creature cannot be targeted.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Untargetable.md

item.title: Invincible
item.description: Creature's HP cannot be reduced.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Invincible.md

item.title: Unstoppable
item.description: Creature cannot be moved by force, and can move and take actions normally regardless of any status.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Unstoppable.md

item.title: Entombed
item.description: The creature is encased in ice, stone etc. They have Total Cover and are Untargetable. Entombed creatures can only perform mental actions or try to escape (usually requiring an athletics check).
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Entombed.md

item.title: Drained
item.description: A stacking condition that decreases all Rolls by 1. Lowers your current and maximum HP by 5 each stack. One stack is removed when Resting for a week straight.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Drained.md

item.title: Dominated
item.description: A creature that is dominated is hit with a powerful charm effect, possessed, or controlled by some other means. They are unable to control their own actions and are subject to the will of another creature.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Dominated.md

item.title: Anchored
item.description: Creature cannot use Teleportation effects. If it attempts to, the action (and ability) is wasted.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Anchored.md

item.title: Wet
item.description: Gain weakness to Electric and Cold Damage. When a wet creature takes Electric or Cold damage, the condition ends.Being wet is something that can come up often in the environment. Only by being drenched in heavy rain, submerged in water or something similar can one be considered wet to the point where this has a mechanical effect.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Wet.md

item.title: Switching Weapons
item.description: At the start of your turn, you can decide what's in your hands from your inventory. You can draw and put away any weapons without penalty. This is a Free Action as long as it's done at the start of your turn. If you decide to change what you're wielding at another point in your turn, it becomes a Swift Action - and you can't do both.Handedness is an important concept here. When you use your hand for something other than a free action, you usually cannot use it for something else on the same turn. The main exception to this is Two-Handed items, which allow you to let go with one hand to perform an action. Any other exceptions should be handled with discretion.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Switching Weapons.md

item.title: Necrosed
item.description: Healing effects that restore HP or grant Temp HP are half as effective (minimum 1 healing).
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Necrosed.md

item.title: Stunned
item.description: A more extreme form of being Dazed. Creature cannot take any actions or movement. Creature is Surprised.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Stunned.md

item.title: Sickened
item.description: Creature takes a penalty to Fortitude and ACC equal to the Sickened value. Otherwise functions like Shaken. Sickened usually wears off after 1 minute out of combat.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Sickened.md

item.title: Shaken
item.description: Creature takes a penalty to Will and Potency equal to the Shaken value. Adding new stacks of Shaken gives all stacks the longest duration of all the effects.Usually, Shaken wears off after 1 minute out of combat.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Shaken.md

item.title: Pacified
item.description: The creature cannot take aggressive actions against enemies with intent to inflict damage or assist its allies in inflicting damage.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Pacified.md

item.title: Fell
item.description: Inflict Knocked Down.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Fell.md

item.title: Grounded
item.description: Through bent wings, malfunctioning magic, or disorientation, the creature is unable to stay airborne. Creatures currently flying immediately plummet and provoke AoOs, but retain enough flight to avoid Fall Damage. This also affects Hover speeds.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Grounded.md

item.title: Fatigued
item.description:
Cannot Charge or Dash. Jump is halved. -10 Athletics and Acrobatics.
Removed on a Short Rest.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Fatigued.md

item.title: Frightened
item.description: Creature cannot move closer to the source of its fear. It has -6 ACC and opposed skill checks against the source of its fear.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Frightened.md

item.title: Blinded
item.description: Sighted creature takes a -10 penalty to Perception and treats all creatures as though they had Total Concealment. Creatures' vision range decreases to 10 ft. Creature is also Surprised.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Blinded.md

item.title: Blurred Vision
item.description: Sighted creature takes a -4 penalty to Perception and treats all creatures as though they had Partial Concealment.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Blurred Vision.md

item.title: Bleeding
item.description: Bleeding creatures take a specified amount of Damage at the start of each of their turns for a specified duration. If no duration is specified, it lasts indefinitely. The DC to stop the bleeding (with the Medicine skill, or magic healing with a CL check) is the attacker's Potency.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Bleeding.md

item.title: Affliction
item.description: A type of permanent negative effect that can usually only be removed by taking some time off to rest, recuperate and relax. Afflictions come in tiers from 1-3. Higher tier afflictions usually require more extreme forms of care to remove. They are similar to Curses.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Affliction.md

item.title: Asleep
item.description: Asleep: This creature is Knocked Down, can take no actions, and cannot be awakened unless it takes damage or an ally uses the Aid action to awaken them. The creature is also Surprised and suffers -20 Perception.If the creature is asleep through natural means, it can use perception to wake up by noticing something amiss.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Asleep.md

item.title: Initiative
item.description:
As a Turn-Based Game, Initiative decides who goes first.Initiative is d10+Reflex. Some bonuses apply specifically to Initiative.
Whoever rolls higher goes first. Ties are broken first by the higher bonus, then PCs take priority.In the event where there are two parties that don't immediately fight, initiative starts when someone takes an aggressive action, such as casting a spell or drawing an arrow. In these cases, where both parties are aware of each other, initiative gets rolled immediately before any actions happen, but the individual that took the aggressive action gains a +10 bonus to their Initiative. This means being the first to say "I attack!" usually means going first.
Certain types of underhanded tactics can affect who goes first, such as using Hands to draw a concealed weapon or Deception for a sucker punch.
Anyone that is not aware of combat is placed below anyone that was aware when initiative was rolled, regardless of their initiative result. This usually happens as a result of Stealth or an attack against sleeping opponents.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Initiative.md

item.title: PC
item.description: Player Character (PC): A character controlled by a player, and not the DM. Players are the main characters of a story, and thus gain port priority in some aspects.Sometimes, a DM will play a special character alongside the players that is treated like a PC. This is normal, but the players can veto such a character's PC status if they feel it is inappropriate.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/PC.md

item.title: NPC
item.description:
Non-Player Character (NPC): Any character that is played by the DM.
These characters usually get placed after PCs to favor the players.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/NPC.md

item.title: DM
item.description: Dungeon Master (DM): The person running the game. This person is the arbiter of the rules, tasked with creating the world, playing all NPCs, and ensuring a fun and fair experience for the players.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/DM.md

item.title: Recharge Abilities
item.description: Regain all uses of your Recharge abilities.When you use this action, you cannot use it again for one minute.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Swift Actions/Recharge Abilities.md

item.title: Rest
item.description: Take a Short Rest or Long Rest.

item.title: Saving Throw
item.description:
Saving Throws (Saves) are Rolls decide the effectiveness of abilities or effects that do not require an Attack. It is typically the affected creature that rolls the save. In order to consider a saving throw a pass, the affected creature must roll higher than the DC of the effect.
The DC of a Saving Throw is usually 10 plus the Level of the effect, or the attacking creature's Potency.
Saves come in 3 forms: Fortitude saves (based on STR), Reflex saves (based on DEX), and Will saves (based on WIS).
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Saving Throws/Saving Throw.md

item.title: Lv
item.description: Level (LV): the level assigned to a creature or effect is used to represent their relative strength in the setting. Level is added to all Rolls (Attacks, Saving Throws, Skills, etc.)
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Lv.md

item.title: Partial Concealment
item.description: Partial Concealment is a Circumstance that grants +4 AC. When you have Partial Concealment, a creature can still see you, but in a limited capacity. Either they can only see your shadow, they're trying to avert your gaze, or there are poor environmental conditions/magic at play.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Cover/Partial Concealment.md

item.title: Long Rest
item.description:
Taking a Long Rest requires being in a place with no immediate threats or hazards for at least 8 hours, during which you sleep to benefit from Natural Healing.
Proper rest requires being in a safe environment with the minimum necessary accommodations to not ache in one's sleep. Lacking any of these requirements results in only restoring half of one's missing HP, or less if the situation is worse, at the DM's discretion. If you are interrupted but spent at least 15 minutes resting, it counts as a Short Rest.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Hitpoints/Long Rest.md

item.title: Healing
item.description: Healing is an effect that restores current HP up to your maximum HP, grants Temp HP, or removes debilitating status conditions.

item.title: Recovering from Defeat
item.description:
After being Defeated for an hour after the last time it took damage, a creature may attempt to shake off the condition with a STR Roll. On a 10 or higher, they lose the Defeated condition, but as long as their HP remains negative, they are Staggered. On a fail, they lose 5 HP.
After successfully recovering, the creature is Drained by d4-LUK. This drain cannot kill the creature.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Hitpoints/Recovering from Defeat.md

item.title: Action-Attack
item.description: Action-Attacks are actions that can either be used as a Standard Action or as an attack with an AS of 1.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Action-Attack.md

item.title: Attack Action
item.description: When you take the Attack Action, you dedicate your turn to all-out offense. This allows you to make a number of attacks up to your highest Attack Speed, in any non-conflicting combination. Attack Speed is a product of which weapon you have on hand, but not all attacks must be with a weapon.Action-Attack are a special type of "action," which by default have an Attack Speed of 1. Most combat spells, combat maneuvers, and special attacks are Action-Attacks. You can also activate these as a regular Standard Action.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Attack Action.md

item.title: Dirty Trick
item.description: Apply clumsy 2, sickened 2 or blurred vision to a creature. They must spend a standard action to get rid of the condition.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Dirty Trick.md

item.title: Drag
item.description: Requires a free hand or prehensile appendage. Target creature stays adjacent to you for the remainder of your turn, up to 30 ft. If the creature is not adjacent to you when you successfully drag, they are automatically pulled adjacent to you. You can choose any space within your natural reach to place the creature in at the end of your drag.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Drag.md

item.title: Roll
item.description: The default die roll for resolving things. This is used to determine the variance expected.In Malon's Marvelous Misadventures, this is a 15-sided die, rolled until a result of a Natural 1 shows up. The amount of rolls (including the one that results in the natural 1) is totaled as the result. For example, if it took 12 rolls, then the result of this "roll" is 12.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Roll.md

item.title: Natural
item.description: A Natural result on a Roll is the result without any bonuses or penalties.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Natural.md

item.title: Delay
item.description: You can wait for a later spot in Initiative. If you're already at the bottom, you can wait until a later round. When you decide to re-enter Initiative, your Initiative changes to the spot you enter.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Free Actions/Delay.md

item.title: Swap Item
item.description: At the start of your turn, you can decide what's in your hands from your inventory. You can draw and put away any weapons without penalty. This is a free action as long as it's done at the start of your turn. If you decide to change what you're wielding at another point in your turn, it becomes a swift action - and you can't do both.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Free Actions/Swap Item.md

item.title: Use Potion
item.description: Retrieve and drink a potion.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Swift Actions/Use Potion.md

item.title: Prepare
item.description: You can prepare swift actions, movement, free actions and standard actions to react to a specific triggering event (Ex: âa goblin opens this door, I walk up to him and shove him off the cliffâ). If the triggering action never happens, you don't get your actions back.When you prepare a standard action to attack, you can only prepare a single attack.You cannot prepare actions outside of Initiative.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Prepare.md

item.title: Disengage
item.description: Your movement is Elusive this turn.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Disengage.md

item.title: Dash
item.description: Double your speed this round.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Dash.md

item.title: Charge
item.description: Move up to your speed in a straight line, and then make an attack.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Charge.md

item.title: Carry
item.description: Carrying an ally allows you to move them with your movement. You must be able to lift the ally, or drag them treating all terrain as difficult terrain. You must use this action every turn you carry an ally. The creature you carry becomes clumsy 2 unless they are defeated or you aren't in combat.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Carry.md

item.title: Administer Potion
item.description: Give a potion to an unconscious ally. You can use potions from either of your inventories.A conscious ally must spend an Immediate Action to drink an administered potion.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Administer Potion.md

item.title: Immediate Action
item.description: Immediate Action: A Swift Action that can occur off-turn. Limited to one per round, shared with Swift Action â you cannot use both in the same round.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Immediate Action.md

item.title: Full-Round Action
item.description: Full-Round Action: This action requires the use of your standard action and all of your free movement. You may still move if you have an ability that allows extra movement as a different action.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Full-Round Action.md

item.title: Luck Check
item.description: When the chance something will happen or fail to happen is based purely on chance, you attempt a Luck Check. You just roll a d10, add (or subtract) LUK and compare the result on the die to the DC.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Ability Scores/Luck Check.md
